editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Humorous Lieutenant, OR, Generous Enemies, A COMEDY: As it is now ACTED by His Majesties Servants, AT THE Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane.

LONDON, Printed for H. N. and Sold by William Chandler at the Peac 〈…〉
the Poultry, and Ralph Smith, at the Bible under the P 〈…〉
the Royal-Exchange in Cornhill. 1697.

list.head: MEN.
list.label: Mr. Harland,
Mr. Cibber.
list.item: KIng Antigonus, An Old Man with Young Desires. Demetrius, Son to Antigonus, in Love with Celia.
list.label: Mr. Simpson,
Mr. Disney,
Mr. Rogers,
list.item: Seleucus, Charinthus, Menippus, 3 Kings, Equal Sharers with Antigonus, of what Alexander had, with United Powers opposing Antigonus.
list.label: Mr. Mills,
list.item: Leontius, A brave Old Merry Souldier, Assistant to Demetrius.
list.label: Mr. Fairbank,
Mr. Essex,
Mr. Provost.
list.item: Timon, Charinthus, Menippus, Servants to Antigonus, and his Vices.
list.label: Mr. Pinkeithman,
list.item: Gentlemen, Friends and Followers of Demetrius.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.label: Mrs. Verbruggen.
list.item: Celia, alias Evanthe, Daughter to Seleucus, Mistriss to Demetrius.
list.label: Mrs. Bullock.
list.item: Leucippe a Baud, Agent to the King's Lust.
list.label: Mrs. Powell.

div.head: PLAYS Sold by William Chandler, and Ralph Smith.
div.p: Assignation, or Love in a Nunnery.
Sir Anthony Love, or the Rambling Lady.
Rule a VVife and have 〈◊〉 VVife.

div.stage: Enter 2 Ushers, and Groomes with Perfumes.

sp.speaker: 1 Vsher.
sp.p: ROund, round, perfume it round, quick, look ye diligently the state be right; Are these the Richest Cushions? Fie, fie, who waits i'th' Wardrobe?

sp.speaker: 2 Vsh.
sp.p: But pray tell me, do you think for certain these Ambassadors shall have this morning Audience?

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: They shall have it: Lord, that you live at Court and understand not? I tell you they must have it.

sp.speaker: 2 Vsh.
sp.p: Upon what necessity?

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: Still you are Ignorant of the Trick of Court, sell your Place.

div.p: And Sow your Grounds, you are not for this Tillage. Ladies, the best way is the upper Lodgings, there you may see at ease.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: We thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: Would you have all these slighted? Who should report then the Embassadors were handsome Men? his Beard a neat one? the fire of his eyes quicker then Lightning, and when it breaks, as blasting? his Legs, tho little ones, yet movers of a Mass of Understanding? Who shall commend their Clothes: who shall take notice of the most wise behaviour of their Feathers? ye live a raw Man here.

sp.speaker: 2 Vsh.
sp.p: I think I do so.

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: Why, whether would you all press?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Good Master Vsher.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: My Wife, and some few of my honest Neighbours here.

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: Prethee be gone thou and thy honest Neighbours, thou look'st like an Ass; why, Whether would you Fish-Face?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: If I might have the honour to see you at my poor House, Sir, a Capon bridled, and sadl'd I'll assure your Worship, a Shoulder of Mutton, and a Bottle of Wine Sir; I know your Brother, he was as like ye, and shot the best at Buts—

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: A—upon thee.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Some Musick I'll assure you too, my Toy, Sir, can play o'th' Virginals.

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: Prethee good Toy take away thy Shoulder of Mutton, it is Flieblown, and Shoulder, take thy Flap along, here's no place for ye; nay then you had best knock'd.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I wou'd fain see him
The glory of this place, makes me remember,
But dye those thoughts, dye all but my desires,
Even those to death are sick too; he's not here,
Nor how my eyes may guide me—

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: What's your business? who keeps the outward door there? here's fine shufling, you wastcoateer you must go back.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There is not,
There cannot be, six days and never see me?
There must not be desire; Sir, Do you think
That if you had a Mistris—

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: Death, she is Mad.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: And were your self an honest Man? it cannot—

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: What a Devil hast thou to do with me or my honesty? Will you be jogging, good nimble Tongue? my fellow Door-keeper?

sp.speaker: 2 Vsh.
sp.p: Prethee let her alone.

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: The King is coming, and shall we have an Agent from the Suburbs come to crave Audience too?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Before I thought ye
To have a little Breeding, some tang of Gentry;
But now I take ye plainly,
Without the help of any Perspectivo,
For that ye cannot alter.

sp.speaker: 1. Vsh.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: An Ass, Sir, you Bray as like one,
And by my Troth, methinks, as ye stand now,
Considering who to kick next, you appear to me
Just with that kind of Gravity, and Wisdom;
Your Place may bear the Name of Gentleman,
But if any of that Butter stick to your Bread—

sp.speaker: 2 Vsh.
sp.p: You must be modester.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Let him use me nobler,
And wear good Clothes to do good Ossices;
They hang upon a Fellow of his Vertue,
As tho they hung on Gibbets.

sp.speaker: 2 Vsh.
sp.p: A parlous Wench.

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: Thrust her into a corner, I'll no more on her.

sp.speaker: 2 Vsh.
sp.p: You have enough, go pretty Maid, stand close, and use that little Tongue with a little more temper.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I thank ye, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Vsh.
sp.p: When the Shews are past, I'll have ye into the Cellar, there wee'l Dine, a very pretty 〈◊〉 , a witty Rogue, and there wee'l be as merry, Can ye be Merry

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: O very merry.

sp.speaker: 2 Vsh.
sp.p: Only our selves; this churlish fellow shall not know.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: 2. Vsh.
sp.p: And can you love a little?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Love exceedingly:
I have cause to love you dear sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Vsh.
sp.p: Then I'll carry ye, and shew you all the Pictures, and the Hangings, the Lodgings, Gardens, and the Walks: and then (sweet) you shall tell me where you lye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Yes marry will I.

sp.speaker: 2 Vsh.
sp.p: And't shall go hard but I'll send ye a Venison Pasty, and a Bottle of Wine.

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: Make room there.

sp.speaker: 2 Vsh.
sp.p: Room there afore, stand close, the Train is coming.

div.stage: Enter King Antigonous, Tymon, Charinthus, Menippus.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Have I yet left a Beauty to Catch Fools?
Yet, yet, I see him not, O what a misery
Is love, expected long, deluded longer!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Conduct in the Embassadors.

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: Make room there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: They shall not wait long Answer—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Yet he comes not.

sp.l: Why are Eyes set on these, and Multitudes
Follow to make these Wonders? O good gods!
What would these look like if my Love were here?
But I am fond, forgetful.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now your grievance,
Speak short, and have as short dispatch.

sp.speaker: 1 Em.
sp.l: Then thus, Sir:
In all our Royal Masters names, We tell you
Ye have done Injustice, broke the bonds of Concord,
And from their equal shares from Alexander
Parted, and so possess'd, not like a Brother,
But as an open Enemy, Ye have hedged in
Whole Provinces, Man'd and maintain'd these Injuries;
And daily with your Sword (though they still honour ye)
Make bloody Roades, take Towns, and ruin Castles,
And still their sufferance feels the weight.

sp.speaker: 2 Em.
sp.l: Think of that Love, Great Sir, that honour'd Friendship
Your self hold with our Masters, think of that strength
When you were all one Body, all one Mind;
When all your Swords strook one way, when your Angers,
Like so many brother billows rose together,
And curling up your foaming crests, defy'd
Even Mighty Kings, and in their falls, entomb'd 'em:
O think of these; and you that have been Conquerors,
That ever led your Fortunes open ey'd,
Chain'd fast by considence; you that Fame courted,
Now ye want Enemies and Men to match ye;
Let not your own Swords seek your ends to shame ye.

div.stage: Enter Demetrius with a Javelin, and Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 3 Em.
sp.l: Choose which you will, or Peace or War,
We come prepar'd for either.

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.p: Room for the Prince there.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Was it the Prince they said! how my heart trembl'd!
'Tis he indeed; What a sweet noble sierceness
Dwels in his eyes? young Meleager like,
When he return'd from slaughter of the Boar,
Crown'd with the loves and honours of the People,
With all the gallant youth of Greece, he looks now,
Who could deny him Love?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Hail Royal Father.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ye are welcome from your Sport; Sir, Do you see this,
You that bring Thunders in your mouths, and Earthquakes Gentlemen,
To shake and totter my Designs? Can you imagine
(You Men of poor and common apprehensions)
Whilst I admit this Man, my Son, this nature
That in one look carries more fire, and sierceness,
Then all your Masters in their lives: dare I admit him,
Admit him thus, even to my side, my Bosome,
When he is fit to rule, when all Men cry him,
And all hopes hang about his head; thus place him,
His Weapon hatch't in blood, all these attending
When he shall make their fortunes, all as sudden
In any Expedition he shall point 'em,
As Arrows from a Tartar's Bow, and speeding,
Dare I do this, and fear an Enemy?
Fear your great Master? yours? or yours?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O Hercules,
Who sayes you do Sir? Is there any thing
In these mens Faces, or their Masters actions
Able to work such wonders?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Now a' speakes:
O I could dwell upon that Tongue for ever.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You call 'em Kings, they never wore those Royalties
Nor in the progress of their Lives ariv'd yet
At any thought of King: Emperial Dignities,
And powerful God-like actions sit for Princes,
They can no more put on, and make 'em sit right,
Then I can with this Mortal hand hold Heaven:
Poor petty Men, nor have I yet forgot
The chiefest honours time, and merit gave 'em:
Lysimachus your Master, at his best,
His highest, and his hopefull'st dignities
Was but Grand master of the Elephants;
Seleucus of the Treasure; and for Ptolomy,
A thing not thought on then, scarce heard of yet,
Some Master of Amunition: and must these Men—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What a brave considence flowes from his spirit?
O sweet young Man!

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Must these hold pace with us,
And on the same Field hang their Memories?
Must these examine what the Wills of Kings are?
Prescribe to their designs, and chain their Actions
To their Restraints? be Friends, and Foes when they please?
Send out their Thunders, and their Menaces,
As if the fate of Mortal things were theirs?
Go home, good Men, and tell your Masters from us,
We do 'em too much honour to force 〈◊〉 'em
Their barren Countries, ruin their vast Cities,
And tell 'em, out of Love, we mean to leave 'em
(Since they will needs be Kings) no more to tread on,
Then they have able Wits, and Powers to manage,
And so we shall befriend 'em: Ha? What does she there?

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: This is your Answer, King.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis like to prove so.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Fie, Sweet, What make you here?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pray ye do not Chide me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You do your self much wrong, and me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pray you pardon me,
I feel my fault, which only was committed.
Through my dear love to you: I have not seen ye,
And how can I live then? I have not spoken to ye—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I know this Week ye have not; I will redeem all.
You are so tender now: think where you are, Sweet.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What other light have I left?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prethee Celia,
Indeed, I'll see ye presently.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have done, Sir:
You will not miss?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: By this, and this, I will not.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis in your will: and I must be obedient.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: No more of these Assemblies.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am commanded.

sp.speaker: 1 Vsh.
sp.l: Room for the Lady there: Madam, my Service—

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: My Coach and't please you, Lady.

sp.speaker: 2 Vsh.
sp.l: Room before there.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: The honour, Madam, but to wait upon you—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My Servants, and my State:
Lord, how they flock now?
Before I was affraid they would have beat me;
How these flies play i'th Sunshine? pray ye no services,
Or if ye needs must play the hobby horses,
Seek out some beauty that assects 'em: farewell,
Nay pray ye spare: Gentlemen I am old enough
To go alone at these years, without Crutches.

sp.speaker: 2. Vsh.
sp.p: Well, I could curse now: but that will not help me, I made as sure account of this Wench now, immediately, Do but consider how the devil has crost me, Meat for my Master she cries, well—

sp.speaker: 3. Em.
sp.l: Once more sir,
We aske your resolutions: peace or war yet?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: War, war, my noble father.

sp.speaker: 1 Em.
sp.l: Thus I fling it:
And fair ey'd peace, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You have your answer;
Conduct out the Embassadours, and give 'em convoies.

sp.speaker: Dem,
sp.l: Tell your high hearted Masters, they shall not seek us,
Nor cool i'th' sield in expectation of us,
We'l ease your men those marches: In their strengths,
And full abilities of mind and courage,
We'l find 'em out, and at their best trim buckle with 'em.

sp.speaker: 3 Em.
sp.l: You will find so hot a Souldiers welcome sir,
Your favor shall not freeze,

sp.speaker: 2 Em.
sp.l: A forward Gentleman,
Pitty the wars should bruse such hopes—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Conduct 'em— Ex- Em.
Now, For this preparation: where's Leontius?
Call him in presently: for I mean in person Gentlemen
My self, with my old fortune—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Royal sir:
Thus low I beg this honour: fame already
Hath every where rais'd trophies to your glory,
And conquest now grown old, and weak with following
The weary marches, and the bloody shockes
You daily set her in: 'tis now scarce honour
For you that never knew to sight, but conpuer,
To sparkle such poor people: the royal Eagle
When she hath tri'd her young ones 'gainst the Sun,
And found 'em right; next teacheth 'them to prey,
How to command on wing, and check below her
Even birds of noble plume; I am your own Sir,
You have found my spirit, try it now, and teach it,
To stoop whole kingdoms: leave a little for me;
Let not your glory be so greedy sir,
To eat up all my hopes; you gave me lise,
If to that life you add not what's more lasting,
A noble name, for man you have made a shadow;
Bless me this day: bid me go on, and lead,
Bid me go on, no less fear'd, then Antigonus,
And to my maiden sword, tye fast your fortune;
I know 'twill sight it self then: dear sir honour me:
Never fair virgin long'd so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Rise, and command then,
And be as fortunate as I expect ye:
I love that noble will; your young companions
Bred up and foster'd with ye, I hope Demetrius, Enter Leon.
You will make souldiers too: they must not leave ye.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Never till life leave us sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O Leontius,
Here's work for you in hand.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I am ev'n right glad sir.
For by my troth, I am now grown old with idleness;
I hear we shall abroad Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, and presently,
But who thinks you commands now?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Who commands Sir?
Methinks my eye should guide me: can there be
(If you your self will spare him so much honour)
Any found out to lead before your armies,
So full of faith, and sire as brave Demetrius?
King Philips Son, at his years was an old Souldier,
'Tis time his fortune be a wing, high time Sir,
So many idle houres, as here he loyters,
So many ever-dying names he loses,
I hope 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis he indeed, and nobly
He shall set forward: draw you all those Garrisons
Upon the frontiers as you pass: to those
Joyne these in pay at home, our ancient souldiers,
And as you go press all the Provinces.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: We shall not need;
Believe this hopeful Gentleman
Can want no swords, nor honest hearts to follow him,
We shall be full, no fear Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You Leontius,
Because you are an old, and faithful servant,
And know the wars, with all its vantages,
Be near to his instructions, lest his youth
Lose valours best companion, staid discretion,
Shew where to lead, to lodge, to charge with safetie;
In execution not to break nor scatter,
But with a provdent anger, follow nobly:
Not covetous of blood, and death, but honour,
Be ever near his watches; cheer his labours,
And where his hope stands faire, provoke his valour;
Love him, and think it no dishonour (my Demetrius)
To wear this Jewel near thee; he is a tri'd one,
And one that even in spight of time, that sunk him,
And frosted up his strength, will yet stand by thee.
And with the proudest of thine enemyes
Exchange for blood, and bravely: take his counsel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your grace hath made me young again, and wanton.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She must be known and suddenly; when you have done
Come in and take your leave Sir, and some few
Prayers along.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do ye know her?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: No, believe Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Did you observe her Tymon?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I look'd on her,
But what she is—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must have that found.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I know my duty, Exit. Am.
You shall be half my father.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All your Servant:
Come Gentlemen, you are resolv'd I am sure
To see these wars.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: We dare not leave his fortunes,
Though most assured death hung round about us.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That Bargain's yet to make;
Be not too hasty, when ye Face the Enemy,
Nor too ambitious to get honour instantly,
But Charge within your Bounds, and keep close Bodies,
And you shall see what sport we'll make these Mad-caps
You shall have Game enough, I warrant ye,
Every Man's Cock shall Fight.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I must go see, Sir:
Brave Sir, as soon as I have taken leave,
I'll meet you in the Park;
Draw the Men thither,
Wait you upon Leonitus.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: We'll attend Sir.

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: But I beseech your Grace, with speed; the sooner
We are i'th' Field—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You could not please me better.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You never saw the wars yet?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Not yet Collonel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: These foolish Mistresses do so hang about ye,
So whimper, and so hug, I know it Gentlemen,
And so intice ye, now ye are i'th' bud;
And that sweet tilting war, with eyes and kisses,
Th' allarums of soft vowes, and sighes, and fiddle faddles,
Spoiles all our trade: You must forget these knick knacks,
A woman at some time of the year, I grant ye
She is necessary; but make no bussiness of her;
How now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Oh Sir, as ill as ever;
We shall have Wars they say; they are Mustering yonder:
Would we were at it once: 〈◊〉 , how it plagues me.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Here's one has served now under Captain Cupid,
And crack't a Pike in's youth: you see what's come on't.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: No, my Disease will never prove so honourable.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Why sure thou hast the best Pox.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: If I have 'em,
I am sure I got 'em in the best Company;
They are Pox of thirty Coates.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Thou hast mew'd 'em finely:
Here's a strange fellow now, and a brave Fellow,
If we may say so of a Pockie Fellow,
(Which I believe we may) this poor Lieutenant;
Whether he have the Scratches, or the Scabs,
Or what a Devil it be, I'll say this for him,
There sights no braver Soldier under Sun, Gentlemen;
Show him an Enemy, his Paine's forgot straight;
And where other Men, by Beds and Bathes have ease,
And easie Rules of Physick, set him in a danger,
A danger, that's a fearful one indeed,
Ye rock him, and he will so play about ye,
Let it be ten to one, he ne'r comes off agaiu;
Ye have his heart: and then he works it bravely,
And throughly bravely: not a Pang remembred:
I have seen him do such things, belief would shrink at.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis strange he should do all this, and Diseas'd so.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am sure 'tis true: Lieutenant, canst thou drink well?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Would I were drunk, Dog-drunk, I might not feel this.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I would take Physick.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: But I would know my Disease first.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Why? it may be the Collick: Canst thou blow backward?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: There's never a Bag-pipe in the Kingdom better.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Is't not a Pleurisie?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: 'Tis any thing
That has the Devil, and Death in't: Will ye March Gentlemen?
The Prince has taken leave.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How know ye that?

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.p: I saw him leave the Court, dispatch his Followers, and met him 〈◊〉 in a bye-street: I think he has some Wench, or such a Toy, to lick over before he go: would I had such another to draw this foolish Pain down.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let's away Gentlemen,
The Prince will stay on us.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Wee'l attend, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Must ye needs go?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Or stay with all dishonour.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Are there not Men enough to Fight?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Fie Celia,
This ill becomes the noble love you bear me;
Would you have your Love a Coward?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No; believe Sir,
I would have him fight, but not so far off from me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Wouldst have it thus? or thus?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If that be fighting—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye Wanton Fool: when I come home again
I'll fight with thee, at thine own Weapon, Celia,
And conquer thee too.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That you have done already,
You need no other Armes to me, but these Sir;
But will you fight your self Sir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thus deep in Blood Dear,
And through the thickest rankes of Pikes.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Spur bravely,
Your firie Courser, beat the Troops before ye,
And cramb the mouth of Death with Executions.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I would do more then these: But prithee tell me,
Tell me, my Faire, Where got'st thou this Male Spirit?
I wonder at thy Mind.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Were I a Man, you would wonder more.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Sure thou wouldst prove a Soldier, and some great Leader.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sure I should do somewhat;
And the first thing I did, I should grow envious,
Extreamly envious of your Youth, and Honour.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And fight against me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Ten to one, 〈◊〉 should do it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou wouldst not hurt me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: In this Mind I am in,
I think I should be hardly brought to strike ye,
Unless 'twere thus; but in my Mans mind—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I should be Friends with ye too, now I think better.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ye are a tall Soldier: Here, take these, and these; this Gold to furnish ye, and keep this Bracelet; Why do you weep now? You a Masculine Spirit?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, I confess, I am a Fool, a VVoman:
And ever when I part with you—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You shall not,
These tears are like prodigious signs, my sweet one,
I shall come back, loden with fame, to honour thee.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I hope you shall:
But then my dear Demetrius,
VVhen you stand Conquerour, and at your Mercy
All People bow, and all things waite your sentence;
Say then your eye (surveying all your conquest)
Finds out a Beauty, even in sorrow excellent,
A constant face, that in the midst of ruine
VVith a forc'd smile, both scornes at Fate, and Fortune:
Say you find such a one, so nobly fortify'd,
And in her figure, all the sweets of Nature?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prithee, no more of this, I cannot find her.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And will run Mad to love ye too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Do ye fear me,
And do you think, besides this Face, this Beauty,
This Heart, where all my hopes are lock'd—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I dare not:
No sure, I think ye honest; wondrous honest.
Pray do not Frown, I Swear ye are.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye may choose.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But how long will ye be away?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I know you are angry now: pray look upon me
I'll ask no more such Questions.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: The Drum beats,
I can no longer stay.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: They do but Call yet:
How fain you would leave my Company.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I wou'd not,
Unless a greater Power then Love Commanded,
Commands my Life, mine Honour.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But a little.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prithee farewell, and be not doubtful of me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I would not have ye hurt: and ye are so 〈◊〉
But good sweet Prince preserve your self, Fight nobly,
But do not thrust his Body; 'tis not yours now,
'Tis mine, 'tis onely mine: do not seek wounds, Sir,
For every drop of Blood you bleed—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will, Celia, I will be careful.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My heart that loves ye dearly.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prithee no more, we must part:
Hark, they March now.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Fye on 〈◊〉 Bawling Drums: I am sure you'll kiss me,
But one Kiss? What a Parting's this?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Here, take me,
And do what thou wilt with me, smother me;
But still remember, if your Fooling with me,
Make me forget the trust—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have done. farewell Sir,
Never look back, you shall not stay, not a minute.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I must have one farewell more.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, the Drums beat;
I dare not slack your Honour; not a hand more,
Onely this Look; the gods preserve, and save ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: WHat have ye found her out?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: We hawe hearkned after her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's that to my desire?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Your grace must give us time, and a little means.

sp.speaker: Ty.
sp.l: She is sure a stranger, if she were bred or known here—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your dull endeavours Enter Menippus.
Should never be employ'd. Welcome Menippus.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I have found her Sir, I mean the place she is lodg'd in; her name is Celia, And much a do I had to purchase that too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dost think Demetrius loves her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Much I fear it,
〈◊〉 nothing that way yet can win for certaine.
I'll tell your grace within this hour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A stranger?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Without all doubt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But how should he come to her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: There lies the 〈◊〉 of the matter hid yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 thou been with thy wife?
No Sir, I am going to her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Go and dispatch, and meet me in the Garden,
And get all out ye can.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I'll do my best Sir.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Blest be thy wife, thou wert an arrant Asse else.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I, she is a stirring woman indeed: there's a brain, brother.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.p: There's not a handsome wench of any mettle within an hundred miles, but her intelligence reaches her, and out-reaches her, and brings her as considently to Court, as to a sanctuary: What had his mouldy brains ever arriv'd at, had not she beaten it out oth' Flint to fasten him? They say she keeps an office of Concealements: there is no young wench, let her be a Saint, Unless she live ith' Center, but she finds her, and every way prepares addresses to her: if my wife would have followed her course Charintbus, her lucky course, I had the day before him: O what might I have been by this time, Brother? But she (forsooth) when I put these things to her, these things of honest thrift, groans, O my conscience, the load upon my conscience, when to make us cuckolds, they have no more burthen then a broodgoose, brother; but let's do what we can, though this wench fail us, another of a now way will be lookt at: Come, let's abroad, and beat our brains, time may for all his wisdome, yet give us a day.

div.head: Seaene. 2.
div.stage: Drum within, Allarme. Enter Demetrius and Leoentius.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will not see 'em fall thus, give me way, Sir,
I shall forget you love me else.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Will ye lose all?
For me to be forgotten, to be hated,
Nay never to have been a Man, is nothing,
So you, and those we have preserv'd from slaughter
Come safely off.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I have lost my self.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are cozn'd.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 am most miserable.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There's no Man so, but he that makes himself so.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will go.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You must not: I shall tell you then,
And tell you true, that Man's unsit to govern,
That cannot guide himself: You lead an Army?
That have not so much Manly suff'rance left ye,
To bear a Loss?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Charge but once more Leonitus,
My Friends and my Companions are engag'd all.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nay give 'em lost, I saw 'em off their Horses,
And the Enemy Master of their Armes; nor could then,
The policy, nor strenth of Man redeem 'em

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And shall I know this, and stand fooling?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By my dead Father's Soul you stir not, Sir,
Or if you do, you make your way through me first.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou art a Coward.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: To prevent a Madman.
None but your Father's Son, durst call me so,
'Death if he did— Must I be scandal'd by ye,
That hedg'd in all the helps I had to save ye?
That, where there was a valiant weapon stirring,
Both search'd it out, and singl'd it, unedg'd it,
For fear it should bite you, Am I a Coward?
Go, get ye up, and tell 'em ye are the King's Son;
Hang all your Ladies Favours on your Crest,
And let them fight their shares; spurre to destruction,
You cannot miss the way: be bravely desperate,
And your young friends before ye, that lost this battel,
Your honourable friends, that knew no order,
Cry out, Antigonus, the old Antigonus,
The wise and fortunate Antigonus,
The great, the valiant, and the fear'd Antigonus,
Has sent a desperate son, without discretion
To bury in an hour his age of honour.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I am ashamed.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis ten to one, I dye with ye:
The coward will not long be after ye;
I scorn to say I saw ye fall, sigh for ye,
And tell a whining tale, some ten years after
To boys and girles in an old chimney corner,
Of what a Prince we had, how bravely spirited;
How young and fair he fell: wee'll all go with ye,
And ye shall see us all, like sacrifices
In our best trim, 〈◊〉 up the mouth of ruine?
Will this faith satisfie your folly? Can this show ye
'Tis not to die we fear, but to die poorly,
To fall, forgotten, in a Multitude?
If you will needs tempt Fortune now she has held ye,
Held ye from sinking up.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Pray do not kill me,
These words pierce deeper then the wounds I suffer,
The smarting wounds of loss.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye are too tender;
Fortune has houres of loss, and houres of honour,
And the most valiant feel them both: take comfort,
The next is ours, I have a Soul descries it:
The angry Bull never goes back for breath,
But when he meanes to arm his fury double.
Let this day set, but not the Memory,
And we shall find a time: How now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I know not: I am mall'd: we are bravely beaten,
All our young Gallants lost.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou art hurt.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I am pepper'd, I was i'th' midst of all: and bang'd of all hands: They made an Anvil of my Head, it rings yet; never so thresh'd: Do you call this Fame? I have fam'd it; I have got Immortal fame, but I'll no more on't; I'll no such scratching Saint to serve hereafter; O' my Conscience I was kill'd above Twenty 〈◊〉 , and yet I know not what a Devil's in't, I crawl'd away, and liv'd again still; I am hurt plaguily, but now I have nothing neer so much pain Colonel, they have sliced me for that Malady.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: All the young Men lost?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I am glad you are here: but they are all i'th' pound Sir, they'l never ride o'r other Mens Corn again, I take it, such frisking, and such flaunting with their Feathers, and such careering with their Mistriss favours; and here must he be pricking out for honour, and there got he a knock, and down goes Pilgarlick, commends his Soul to his She Saint, and Exit. Another spurs in there, cries, Make room Villaines, I am a Lord, scarce spoken, but with reverence a Rascal takes him o'r the Face, and fells him, there lies the Lord, the Lord be with him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now Sir,
Do you find this truth?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I would not.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Pox upon it,
They have such tender Bodies too; such Cullisses,
That one good handsome blow breaks 'em in pieces.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How stands the Enemy?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Even cool enough too: for to say truth, he has been shrewdly heated, the Gentleman no doubt will fall to his Jewlips.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He Marches not i'th'-tail on's.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: No, plague take him, he'll kiss our Tailes as soon; he looks upon us, as if he would say, If ye will turn again, Friends, we will belabour you a little better, and beat a little more care into your Coxcombs. Now shall we have damnable Ballads out against us, most wicked Madrigals: and ten to one, Collonel, Sung to such lowsie, lamentable Tunes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou art Merry,
How e're the Game goes: good Sir be not troubled,
A better day will draw this back again.
Pray go, and cheer 〈◊◊〉 , and lead 'em 〈◊〉 ,
They are hot, and 〈◊〉 .
I'll do any thing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 , send one presentlie away To 'th' King, and let him know our state: and 〈◊〉 ye, be sure the messenger advise his Majesty to comfort up the Prince: he's full of sadness.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: When shall I get a Surgeon? this hot weather,
Unless I be well pepper'd, I shall stink Colonel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Go, I'll prepare thee one.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: If ye catch me then,
Fighting again, I'll eat hay with a horse.

div.head: Scaene 3.
div.stage: Leucippe (reading) and two Maids at a Table writing.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Have ye written to Merione?

sp.speaker: 1. Ma.
sp.l: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: And let her understand the hopes she has
If she come speedily—

sp.speaker: 1. Ma.
sp.l: All these are specified.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: And of the chaine is sent her,
And the rich stuffe to make her shew more handsome here?

sp.speaker: 1. Ma.
sp.l: All this is done, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: What have you dispatcht there?

sp.speaker: 2. Ma.
sp.l: A letter to the Countrey maid, and't please ye.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A pretty girle, but peevish, plaguy peevish:
Have ye bought the embordyered gloves, and that purse for her,
And the new Curle?

sp.speaker: 2. Ma.
sp.l: They are ready packt up Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Her maiden-head will yield me, let me see now, She is not fifteen they say: for her complexion—Cloe, Cloe, Cloe, here, I have her, Cloe, the Daughter of a Countrey gentleman; Her age upon fifteen: now her complexion, a lovely brown; here 'tis; eyes black and rolling, The body neatly built: she strikes a Lute well, sings most inticingly: these helps consider'd, Her maiden-head will amount to some three hundred, or three hundred and fifty crowns; 'twill bear it handsomly. Her father's poor, some little share deducted, to buy him a hunting Nag: I, 'twill be pretty: Who takes care of the Merchants wife.

sp.speaker: 1. Ma.
sp.l: I have wrought her.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: You know for whom she is?

sp.speaker: 1. Ma.
sp.p: Very well, Madam, though very much ado, I had to make her apprehend that happiness.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: These kind are subtile:
Did she not cry and blubber when ye urg'd her.

sp.speaker: 1. Ma.
sp.l: O most extremly, and swore she would rather perish.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Good signs, very good signs, symptoms of easie nature. Had she the plate?

sp.speaker: 1. Ma.
sp.l: She lookt upon't, and left it, and turn'd again and view'd it.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Very well still.

sp.speaker: 1. Ma.
sp.l: At length she was content to let it lye there.
Till I call'd for't, or so.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: She will come?

sp.speaker: 1. Ma.
sp.l: Do you take me
For such a fool, I would part without that promise?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: The Chambers next the park.

sp.speaker: 2. Ma.
sp.l: The Window Madam, you bad me look upon.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Hang her, she is musty:
She is no Mans meat; besides, she is poor and sluttish:

Where lies old
〈◊〉
now, you are so long now—

sp.speaker: 2 Ma.
sp.l: Thisbe, Thisbe, This. Agent Thisbe, O I have her,
She lies now in Nicopolis.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Dispatch a Packet, and tell her, her Superiour here commands her, the next Month not to fail, but see deliver'd here to our use, some Twenty young and handsome, as also able Maids, for the Court service, as she will answer it: we are out of beauty, Utterly out, and rub the time away here, With such blown stuff, I am asham'd to send it. [Knock within.] Who's that? look out, to your business maid, there's nothing got by idleness: There is a Lady, Which if I can but buckle with, Altea, A, A, A, A, Altea, young, and married, and a great lover of her husband, well, not to be brought to Court: say ye so? I am sorry, the Court shall be brought to you then: how now, who is't?

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: An ancient Woman, with a Maid attending, a pretty Girle, but out of Cloathes; for a little Money, it seems she would put her to your bringing up, Madam,

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Let her come in. Would ye ought with us, good Woman? I pray be short, we are full of Business.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: I have a tender Girle here, and please your Honour.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: That hath a great desire to serve your Worship.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: It may be so; I am full of Maids.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: She is young, forsooth—
And for her Truth; and as they say her bearing.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Ye say well: come ye hither, Maid, let me feel your Pulse, 'tis somewhat weak but Nature will grow stronger; let me see your Leg, she treads but low ith' Pasterns.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: A Cork heel, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: We know what will do it, without your aim, good Woman: What do you pitch her at? she's but a slight Toy—cannot hold out long.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Even what you think is meet.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Give her Ten Crowns, we are full of business, she is a poor Woman, let her take a Cheese home: Enter the Wench in the Office.

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.l: What's your Name, Sister?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Phebe, for sooth.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: A pretty Name; 'twill do well: Go in, and let the other Maid instruct ye Phebe;

Let my old Velvet Skirt be made sit for her, I'll put her into action for a Wastcoat, and when I have rigg'd her up once, this small Pinnace shall sail for Gold, and good store too: Who's there? [Knocks within.] Lord, shall
we never have any case in this World? still troubled? still molested? What would you have? I cannot furnish ye faster then I am able. [Enter Menippe. And ye were my Husband a Thousand times, I cannot do it; at least a dozen Poasts are gone this Morning for several parts of the Kingdom: I can do no more but pay 'em, and instruct 'em.
Prethee, good sweet heart, I come not to disturb thee, nor discourage thee, I know thou labour'st truly: hark in thine ear.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Ha? What do you make so dainty on't? look there, I am an Ass, I can do nothing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Celia? I, this is she; a stranger born.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: What would you give for more now?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Prithee, my best Leucippe, ther's much hangs on't, lodg'd at the end of Marse's street? that's true too; at the sack of such a Town, by such a Souldier preserv'd a prisoner: and by Prince Demetrius bought from that man again, maintain'd, and favourd: How came you by this knowledge?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Poor weak man, I have a thousand eyes, when thou art sleeping, abroad, and full of business.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: You never tri'd her;

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: No, she is beyond my level; so hedg'd in by the Princes insinite love, and favour to her—

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: She is a handsome wench.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A delicate, and knows it; and out of that proof arms her self.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Come in then; I have a great design from the King to you, and you must work like wax now.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: On this Lady;

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: On this, and all your wits call home.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I have done Toyes in my time of some note; old as I am, I think my brains will work without barme, take up the Books.

div.head: Scaene. 4.
div.stage: Enter Antigonus, Tymon, Lords, and a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No face of sorrow for this loss? 'twill choak him,
Nor no man miss a friend, I know his nature
So deep imprest with grief, for what he has suffer'd,
That the least adding to it, adds to his ruin;
His loss is not so insinite, I hope Souldier.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Faith neither great, nor out of discretion, the young men out of heat.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I guess the manner.

sp.speaker: 〈◊〉 Men.
sp.l: The Prince and't like your Grace—s.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are welcome home Sir;
Come, no more sorrow, I have heard your fortune,
And I my self have trid the like: clear up man,
I will not have ye take it thus if I doubted.
Your fear had lost; and that you had turn'd your back to 'em,
Basely besought their mercies—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No, no, by this hand Sir,
We fought like honest and tall men.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I know't Leontius; or if I thought
Neglect of rule, having his counsel with ye,
Or too vain-glorious appetite of fame,
Your men forgot, and scatter'd—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: None of these Sir,
He shew'd himself a noble gentleman,
Every way apt to rule.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: These being granted;
Why should you think you have done an act so hainous,
That nought but discontent dwells round about ye?
I have lost a Battel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I, and fought it hard too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With as much means as Man—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Or Devil could urge it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Twenty to one of our side now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Turn Tables,
Beaten like Dogs again, like Owles, you take it
To heart for flying but a Mile before 'em,
And to say truth, 'twas no flight neither Sir,
'Twas but a walk, a handsome walk,
I have tumbl'd with this old Body, beaten like a Stock-fish,
And stuck with Arrows, like an arming Quiver,
Blouded and bang'd, almost a day before 'em,
And glad I have got off then. Here's a Mad Shaver,
He sights his share I am sure, when e're he comes to't;
Yet I have seen him trip it titely too,
And cry, the Devil take the hindmost.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I learn'd it of my betters.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Budge at this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Has Fortune but one Face;

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: In her best Vizard, methinks she looks but Lowzily.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Chance, though she faint now,
And sink below our expectations,
Is there no hope left strong enough to buoy her?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis not this day, I sled before the Enemy,
And lost my People, left mine honour murder'd,
My Mayden honour, never to be ransom'd,
(Which to a noble Soul is too too sensible)
Afflicts me with this sadness; most of these,
Time may turn straight again, experience perfect,
And new Swords, cut new ways to nobler Fortunes.
O have lost—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: As you are mine forget it:
I do not think it loss.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.l: O Sir, forgive me,
I have lost my Friends, those worthy Soules bred with me,
I have lost my self, they were the pieces of me;
I have lost all Arts, my Schooles are taken from me,
Honour and Armes, no emulation left me:
I liv'd to see these Men lost, look'd upon it:
These Men that twin'd their loves to mine, their 〈◊〉 ,
O shame of shames, I saw, and could not save 'em,
This carries Sulphure in't, this burnes and boyles me,
And like a fatal Tombe bestrides my Memory.

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: This was hard fortune, but if alive and taken,
They shall be ransom'd; let it be at Millions.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: They are dead, they are dead.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: When would he weep for me thus? I may be dead, and Powder'd.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Good Prince, grieve not: we are not certain of their Deaths: the Enemy, though he be hot and keen, yet holds good Quarter. What Noise is this?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: He does not follow us?
Give me a Steeple top.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: They live, they live, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hold up your Manly Face;
They live, they'r here Son.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: These are the Men.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: They are, and live to honour ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How scap't ye, noble Friends? methought I saw ye
Even in the jaws of Death.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Thanks to our folly,
That spurr'd us on; we were indeed hedg'd round in't,
And ev'n beyond the hand of succour beaten,
Unhors'd, disarm'd: and what we lookt for then Sir,
Let such poor weary Souls that hear the Bell Toll,
And see the Grave a digging, tell.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: For Heaven sake
Delude mine eyes no longer: How came ye off?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l:
Against all expectation: the brave
〈◊〉 ,
I think this day enamour'd on your Vertue,
When, through the Troops, he saw you shoot like Lightning;
And at your Manly Courage all took sire,
And after that, the Misery we fell too,
The never-certain fate of War considering,
As we stood all before him, Fortunes ruines,
Nothing but Death expecting, a short time
He made a stand upon our Youths and Fortunes,
Then with an eye of Mercy inform'd his judgment,
How yet unripe we were, unblown, unharden'd,
Unsitted for such fatal ends; he cry'd out to us,
Go, Gentlemen, commend me to your Master,

To the most high, and Powerful Prince
〈◊〉 ,
Tell him, the 〈◊〉 he showed against me
This day, the Virgin-valour, and true sire
Deserves, even from an Enemy, this Courtesie;
Your Lives and Armes freely I'll give 'em: than him,
And thus we are return'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Faith 'twas well done;
'Twas bravely done; Was't not a noble part, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Had I been there, up had I gone, I am sure on't;
These noble tricks, I never durst trust 'em yet.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let me not live, and wer't not a famed honesty,
It takes me such a tickling way: now would I wish Heaven,
But ee'n the happiness, ee'n that poor Blessing,
For all the sharp 〈◊〉 thou hast sent me,
But ee'n i'th' head o'th' Field to take Seleucus.
I should do somewhat memorable: 〈◊〉 , sad still.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent,
sp.l: Do you grieve we are come off?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Unransom'd was it?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: It was Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And with such a fame to me?
Said ye not so?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye have heard it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O Leonitus,
Better I had lost 'em all: my self had perish'd
And all my Father's hopes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Mercy upon ye,
What ayle ye, Sir? 'Death, do not make sools 〈◊〉 ,
Neither go to Chuech, nor tarry at home,
That's a 〈◊〉 Horn-pipe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's now your Grief, Demetrius?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Did he not beat us twice?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He beat a Pudding;
Beat us but once.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Has beat me twice, and beat me to a Coward,
Beat me to nothing.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Is not the Devil in him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I pray it be not worse.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Twice conquer'd me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Bear Witness all the World, I am a 〈◊〉 here.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: With valour 〈◊〉 he strook me, then with honour:
That stroak Leontius, that stroak, do'st thou not feel it?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Where abouts was it? for I remember nothing yet.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: All these Gentlemen that were his Prisoners—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He set 'em free, Sir, with Armes and Honour.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: There, there, now thou hast it
At mine own Weapon, Courtesie, h'as beaten me,
At that I was held a Master in, he has cow'd me,
Hotter then all the dint oth' sight he has charg'd me:
Am I not now a wretched Fellow? think on't;
And when thou hast examin'd all ways honourable,
And find'st no door left open to requite this,
Conclude I am a Wretch, and was twice beaten.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have observ'd your way, and understand if,

And equal love it as
〈◊〉 ,
My noble Childe, thou shalt not fall in Vertue,
I and my Power will sink first: you Leontius,
Wait for a new Commission, ye shall out again,
And instantly: you shall not lodge this night here,
Not see a friend, nor take a blessing with ye,
Before ye be i'th' field: the enemy is up still,
And still in full design: Charge him again, Son,
And either bring home that again thou hast lost there,
Or leave thy body by him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye raise me,
And now I dare look up again, Leontius.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I, I, Sir, I am thinking who we shall take of 'em,
To make all straight; and who we shall give to th' devil.
What saist thou now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I say nothing.
Lord what aile I, that I have no mind to sight now?
I find my constitution mightily alter'd
Since I came home: I hate all noises too,
Especially the noise of Drums; I am now as well
As any living man; why not as valiant?
To fight now, is a kind of vomit to me,
It goes against my stomach.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Good Sir, presently;
You cannot do your Son, so fair a favour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis my intent: I'll see ye march away too;
Come, get your men together presently, Leontius,
And press where please you, as you march.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: We go Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wait you on me, I'll bring ye to your command,
And then to fortune give you up.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye love me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Go, get the drums, beat round, Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Hark ye Sir,
I have a foolish business they call marriage.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: After the wars are done.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: The partie staies Sir,
I have giv'n the Priest his money too: all my friends Sir,
My father and my mother.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Will you go forward?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: She brings a pretty matter with her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Half a dozen Bastards.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Some sorry Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A goodly 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I mean Sir, pounds a year; I'll dispatch the matter,
'Tis but a night 〈◊〉 two; I'll overtake ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The 2 old legions, yes: where lies the horse-quarter?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And if it be a boy, I'll even make bold Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Away with your Whore,
A plague o' your Whore, you damn'd rogue,
Now ye are cur'd and well; must ye be clicketing?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I have broke my mind to my Ancient, in my absence,
He's a sufficient gentleman.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Get forward.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Only receive her portion.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Get ye forward;
Else I'll bang ye forward.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Strang Sir,
A Gentleman and an officer cannot have the liberty
To do the office of a man.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Shame light on thee,
How came this Whore into thy head?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: This Whore Sir?
'Tis strange, a poor whore.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Do not answer me:
Troop, Troop away: do not name this whore again,
Or think there is a whore.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: That's very hard Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: For if thou dost, look too't, I'll have thee guelded,
I'll walk ye out before me: not a word more.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Ye are the Mistress of the house ye say,
Where this young Lady lyes.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: For want of a better.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You may be good enough for such a purpose:
When was the Prince with her? answer me directly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Not since he went a warring.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Very well then:
What 〈◊〉 copulation are you privie too
Between these two? be not afraid, we are women,
And may talk thus amongst our selves, no harm in't.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: No sure, there's no harm in't, I conceive that;
But truely, that I ever knew the gentlewoman
Otherwise given, then a hopeful gentlewoman—

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You'll grant me the Prince loves her?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: There I am with ye.
And the Gods bless her, promises her mightily.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Stay there a while. And gives her gifts?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Extreamly;
And truely makes a very Saint of her.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I should think now,
(Good woman let me have your judgement with me,
I see 'tis none of the worst: Come sit down by me)
That these two cannot love so tenderly—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Being 〈◊◊〉 as they are too—

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You say well—
But that methinks some further promises—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Yes, yes,
I have heard the Prince swear he would marry her.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Very well still: they do not use to fall out?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: The tenderest Chickens to one another,
They cannot live an hour assunder.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I have done then;
And be you gone; you know your charge, and do it.
You know whose will it is; if you transgress it—
That is, if any have access, or see her,
Before the Kings will be fulfill'd—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Not the Prince, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You'll be hang'd if you do it, that I'll assure ye.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: But ne're the less, I'll make bold to obey ye.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Away, and to your business then.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: 'Tis done, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l:
THou hast taken wondrous pains; but yet
〈◊〉 ,
You understood not of what blood, and 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I labour'd that, but cannot come to know it.
A Greek I am sure she is, she speaks this Language.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is she so excellent handsome?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Most inticing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sold for a prisoner?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Yes Sir,
Some poor creature.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And he loves tenderly?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: They say extreamly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis well prevented then yes, I perceiy'd it:
When he took leave now, he made a hundred stops,
Desir'd an hour, but half an hour, a minute,
Which I with anger cross'd; I knew his business,
I knew 'twas she he hunted on; this journey, man,
I beat out suddenly for her cause intended,
And would not give him time to breath. When comes she?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: This morning Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lodge her to all delight then: For I would have her tri'd toth'test: I know she must be some crackt Coyn, not sit his Traffique; which, when we have found, the shame will make him leave her, or we shall work a nearer way, I'll bury him, and with him all the hopes I have cast upon him, ere he shall dig his own Grave in that Woman: you know which way to bring her: I'll stand close there, to view her as she passes: And do you hear Menippus, observe her with all sweetness: humour her, 'twill make her lie more careless to our purposes. Away, and take what helpes you please.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I am gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Governess, From whom was this Gown sent me; Prithee be serious true; I will not wear't else: 'Tis a handsome one.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: As though you know not?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: No Faith: But I believe for certain too, yet I wonder, because it was his caution, this poor way, still to preserve me from the curious searchings of greedy eyes.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You have it: Does it please you?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis very rich methinks too, prithee tell me—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: From one that likes you well, never look coy, Lady;
These are no gifts, to be put off with poutings.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Powtings, and Gifts? Is it from any stranger?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You are so curious, that there is no talking to ye. What if it be I pray ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Unpin good Governess, Quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Quick, good Governess: Fie on't, How beastly it becomes me? poorly? A trick put upon me? well said Governess: I vow I would not wear it—out, it smells musty. Are these your tricks? now I begin to smell it abominable musty; Will ye help me? The Prince will come again—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You are not Mad sure?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: As I live Ill' cut it off: a Pox upon it; for sure it was made for that use; Do you bring me Livories? Stales to catch Kites? Dost thou Laugh too, thou base Woman?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I cannot chuse, if I should be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Abuse me, and then Laugh at me too?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I do not abuse ye: Is it abuse to give him Drink that's Thirsty?
You want Clothes; Is it such a heinous sin I beseech ye, to see you stor'd?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There is no greater wickedness then this way.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: What way?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I shall Curse thee fearfully, if thou provok'st me further: and take heed, Woman; my 〈◊〉 never miss.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Curse him that sent it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Tell but his Name—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You dare not Curse him,

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Dare not I? By this fair light—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You are so full of Passion—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Dare not be good? Be honest? Dare not Curse him?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I think you dare not: I believe so.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Speak him.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Up with your Valour then, up with it bravely, and take your full charge.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If I do not, hang me; tell but his Name.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: 'T was Prince Demetrius sent it:
Now, now, give sire, kill him ith' eye now Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Is he come home?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: It seems so; but your Curse now.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You do not lie, I hope.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You dare not Curse him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Prithee do not abuse me: Is he come home indeed?
For I would now with all my heart believe thee.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Nay, you may chuse: alas, I deal for Strangers, that send ye scurvy
Musty Gowns, stale Livories: I have my Tricks.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis a good Gown, a handsome one; I did but jest; Where is he?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: He that sent it—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: How? he that sent it? Is't come to that again? thou canst not be so foolish prithee speak out, I may mistake thee.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I said he that sent it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Curse o' my life: Why dost thou vex me thus? I know thou meanst Demetrius, dost thou not? I charge thee speak truth: if it be any other, thou knowst the charge he gave thee, and the justice his anger will inflict, if e're he know this, as know he shall, he shall, thou spiteful Woman, thou beastly Woman; and thou shalt know to late too, and feel too sensible, I am no Ward, no Sale-stuff for your Money-Merchants that sent it? Who dare send me, or how durst thou, thou—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: What you please: for this is ever the reward of service. The Prince will bring the next himself.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: 'Tis strange that you should deal so peevishly: beshrew ye, you have put me in a heat.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I am sure ye have kill'd me: I ne're receiv'd such language: I can but wait upon ye, and be your drudge; keep a poor life to serve ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You know my nature is too easie, Governess,
And you know now, I am sorry too: how does he?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: O God, my head.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Prethee be well, and tell me, did he speak of me, since he came? nay, see now, if thou wilt leave this tyranny? good sweet governess: did he but name his Celia? look upon me, upon my faith I meant no harm: here, take this, and buy thy self some trifles: did a good Girle?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: He loves ye but too dearly.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That's my good Governess.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: There's more cloathes making for ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: More cloathes?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: More: richer and braver; I can tell ye that news; And twenty glorious things.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To what use?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Ye are too good for our house now: we poor wretches Shall lose the comfort of ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, I hope not.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: For ever lose ye Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Lose me? wherefore? I hear of no such thing.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: 'Tis sure it must be so: you must shine now at Court: such preparation, such hurry, and such hanging rooms—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Toth' Court wench? Was it toth' Court thou saidst?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You'll find it so.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Stay, stay, this cannot be.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I say it must be: I hope to find ye still the same good Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Toth' Court? this stumbles me: art sure for me, wench, this preperation is?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: She is perilous crafty: I fear too honest for us all too. Am I sure I live?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Toth' Court? this cannot down: what should I do there? why should he on a sudden change his mind thus, and not make me acquainted? sure he loves me; his vow was made against it, and mine with him: At least while this King liv'd: he will come hither, and see me ere I go?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Wou'd some wise woman had her in working: that I think he will not, because he means with all joy there to meet ye. Ye shall hear more within this hour?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: A Courtier? what may the meaning be? sure he will see me if he be come, he must: Hark ye Governess, what age is the King of?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: He's an old man, and full of business.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I fear too full indeed: what Ladies are there?
I would be loath to want good company.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Delicate young Ladies, as you would desire;
And when you are acquainted, the best company.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis very well: prethee go in, let's talk more.
For though I fear a trick, I'll bravely try it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I see he must be cunning, knoks this 〈◊〉 down

div.head: Scaene 3.
div.stage: Enter Lieutenant, and Leontius. Drums within.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You shall not have your will, sirrah, are ye running?
Have ye gotten a toy in your heels? Is this a season,
When honour pricks ye on, to prick your 〈◊〉 up
After your Whore, your Hobby-Horse?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Why look ye now: What a strange Man are you? Would you have a Man fight at all houres all alike.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Do but fight something; but half a blow, and put thy Stomach to't: turn but thy face, and do but make Mouthes at 'em.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: And have my Teeth knockt out; I thank ye heartily, ye are my dear Friend.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What a Devil ails thee? Dost long to be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I make no suit for't: but rather then I would live thus out of Charity, continually in brawling—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Art thou not he? I may be cozn'd—

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I shall be discover'd.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That in the midst of thy most hellish pains, when thou wert crawling sick, didst aim at wonders, when thou wert mad with pain?

sp.speaker: Lieu
sp.p: Ye have found the cause out; I had ne're been mad to sight else: I confess, Sir, the daily torture of my side that vext me, made me as daily careless what became of me, till a kind Sword there wounded me, and eas'd me; 'twas nothing in my valour fought; I am well now, and take some pleasure in my life: methinks now it shews as mad a thing to me to see you 〈◊〉 , and kill one another foolishly for Honour, as 'twas to you, to see me play the Coxcombe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And wilt thou ne're fight more?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Ith' mind I am in.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nor never be sick again?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I hope I shall not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Prethee be sick again; prethee, I beseech thee,
Be just so sick again.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I'll just be hang'd first.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: If all the Arts that are can make a Collick, therefore look to't: or if imposthumes, mark me, as big as foot-balls—

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Deliver me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Or stones of ten pound weight i'th' kidneys through 〈◊〉 and ugly dyets may be gather'd; I'll feed ye up my self Sir, I'll prepare ye, you cannot sight, unless the devil tear ye, you shall not want provocations, I'll 〈◊〉 ye, I'll have thee have the tooth-ach, and the head-ach.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Good Collonel, I'll do any thing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
No, no, nothing—then will I have thee blown with a pair of Smiths bellowes, because ye shall be sure to have a round gale with ye, sil'd full of oyle, o' devil, and
〈◊〉 fortis, and let these work, these may provok.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Good Colonel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Will Roasting do thee any good?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Nor Basting neither, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Marry that goes hard.

sp.speaker: I Gent.
sp.p: Where are you Colonel
The Prince expects ye Sir; has hedg'd the Enemy within a straight, where all the hopes and valours of all Men living cannot force a passage, he has 'em now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I knew all this before Sir,
I chalk'd him out his way: But do you see that thing there;

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Nay, good sweet Colonel 〈◊◊〉 a little.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That thing?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: What thing? I see the brave Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Rogue, What a Name hast thou lost?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: You may help it; yet you may help it: I'll do ye any Courtesie: I know you love a Wench well.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Look upon him; Do you look too.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: What should I look on?
I come to tell ye, the Prince stays your Direction,
We have 'em now ith' Coop, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let 'em rest there,
And chew upon their Miseries: but look first—

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I cannot sight for all this.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Look on this Fellow.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: I know him; 'tis the valiant brave Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Can'st thou hear this, and play the Rogue, steal off quickly,
Behind me quickly, neatly do it,
And rush into the thickest of the Enemy,
And if thou kill'st but two.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: You may excuse me, 'tis not my fault: I dare not sight.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Be rul'd yet,
I'll beat thee on; go wink and sight: A plague upon your sheeps heart.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: What's all this matter?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Nay I cannot shew ye.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Here's Twenty pound, go but smell to 'em.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Alas Sir, I have taken such a cold, I can smell nothing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I can smell a Rascal, a rank Rascall:
Fye, how he stinks, stinks like a tyred Jade.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why, that Sir, Do not you smell him?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Smell him?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I must endure.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Stinks like a dead Dog, Carrion—There's no such damnable smell under Heaven, as the faint sweat of a Coward: Will ye sight yet?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Nay, now I desie ye; ye have spoke the 〈◊〉 ye can of me, and if 〈◊〉 Man should take what you say to the heart—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: God a mercy, God a mercy with all my heart; here I forgive thee; and fight, or fight not, do but go along with us, and keep my Dog.

sp.l: I love a good Dog naturally.

sp.speaker: 〈◊〉 Gent.
sp.l: What's all this stir, Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Nothing, Sir, but a slight matter of Argument.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Pox take thee. Sure I shall love this Rogue, he's so pretty a Coward: Come, Gentlemen, let's up now, and if fortune dare play the Slut again, I'll never more Saint her; Come, Play-fellow, come, prithee come up; come Chicken, I have a way shall sit yet: A tame knave —Come, look upon us.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I'll tell ye who does best Boyes.

div.head: Scaene 4.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I saw her coming out.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who waits 〈◊〉 her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Tymon, Charinthus, and some other Gentlemen
By me appointed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where's your Wife;

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Shee's ready to entertain her here Sir; and some Ladies fit for her Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How shews she in her trim now?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Oh most divinely sweet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prithee speak softly, How does she take her comming?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: She bears it bravely; but what she thinks—For Heaven's sake
Sir preserve me—If the Prince chance to sind this.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Peace ye Old Fool; She thinks to meet him here.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: That's all the Project.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Was she hard to bring;

sp.p: No, she believ'd it quickly, and quickly made her self sit, the Gown a little, and those new things she has not been acquainted with, at least in this place, where she liv'd a Prisoner, troubled and stirr'd her Mind: But believe me, Sir, she has worn as good, they sit so apted to her; and she is so great a Mistriss of disposure: Here they come now: but take a full view of 〈◊〉 .

div.stage: Enter Celia, Tymon, Charinthus, and Gent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How cheerfully she looks? How she 〈◊〉 all?
And how she views the place? she is very young sure:
That was an admirable Smile, a catching one,
The very twang of Cupids Bow Sung to it:
She has two-edg'd eyes, they kill o'both sides.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: She makes a stand, as though she would speak.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Be still then.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Good Gentlemen, trouble your selves no further,
I had thought sure to have met a noble Friend here.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Ye may meet many Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Such as you are I covet few or none, Sir.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: VVill you walk this way,
And take the sweets oth' Garden? cool and close, Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Methinks this open Air's far better, tend ye that way.
Pray where's the Woman came along?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What Woman?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: The Woman of the House I lay at.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Woman; Here was none came along sure.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sure I am 〈◊〉 then: Pray where's the Prince?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: He will not be long from ye, we are his humble servants.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I could Laugh now, to see how finely I am cozn'd: yet I fear not, for sure I know a way to scape all dangers.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Madam, your Lodgings lye this way.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My Lodgings? for 〈◊◊〉 Sir, what office do I bear here?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: The great commander of 〈◊〉 hearts.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You have hit it. I thank your sweet-heart for it. Who are these now?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Ladies that come to serve ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Well consider'd, are you my servants?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Servants to your pleasures.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I dare believe ye, but I dare not trust ye: catch'd with a trick? well, I must bear it patiently: methinks this Court's a neat place: all the people of such resin'd a size—

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: This is no poor rogue.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Were it a Paradice to please your fancy,
And entertain the sweetness you bring with ye;

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Take breath; you are fat and many words may melt ye, this is three Bawds beaten into one; bless me heaven, what shall become of me? I am 〈◊〉 pitfal: o' my conscience, this is the old viper, and all these little ones creep every night into her belly; do you hear plump servant, and my little sucking Ladies, you must teach me, for I know you are excellent at carriage, how to behave my self, for I am rude yet, but you say the Prince will come?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Will flie to see you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: For look you if a great man, say the King now should come and visit me?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: She names ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Peace fool.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And offer me a kindness, such a kindness.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I, such a kindness.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: True Lady such a kindness, what shall that kindness be now?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A witty Lady, learn little ones, learn.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Say it be all his favour.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: And a sweet saying 'tis

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And I grow peevish?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You must not be neglectful.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: There's the matter, there's the main doctrin now, and I may miss it; Or a kind hansome Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You say well.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: They'l count us basely bred.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Not freely nurtur'd.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I'll take thy counsel.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: 'Tis an excellent woman.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I find a notable volume here, a learned one; which way? for I would fain be in my chamber; in truth sweet Ladies, I grow weary; sie, how hot the air beats on me?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: This way Madam?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Now by mine honour, I grow wondrons faint too.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Your fans sweet Gentlewomen, your fans.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Since I am foold, [ 〈◊〉 .]
I'll make my self some sport, though I pay dear for't,

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: You see now what a manner of woman she is Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou art an asse.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Is this a fit love for the Prince?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A coxcombe:
Now by my crown a dainty wench, a sharp wench,
And a matchless spirit: how she Jeer'd 'em?
How carelesly she scoff'd 'em? use her nobly;
I would I had not seen her: wait anon,
And then you shall have more to trade upon.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: We must keep a round, and a strong watch to night, the Prince will not charge the Enemy till the morning: but for the trick I told ye for this rascal, this rogue, that health and strong heart makes a coward.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I, if it take.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ne're fear it, the Prince has it, and if he let it fall, I must not know it; he will suspect me presently: but you two may help the plough.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: That he is sick again—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Extreamly sick: his disease grown incurable.
Never yet found, nor touch'd at.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Well, we have it
And here he comes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The Prince has been upon him, what a flatten face he has now? It takes believe it; how like an asse he looks?
I feel no great pain, at least, I think I do not; yet I feel sensibly I grow extreamely faint: how cold I sweat now?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: So, so, so.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: And now 'tis ev'n too true, I feel a pricking, a pricking, a strang pricking: how it tingles? and as it were a slitch too: the Prince told me, and every one cri'd out I was a dead man; I had thought I had been as well—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Upon him now Boyes, and do it most demurely.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: How now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I thank ye Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: 'Life, how looks this Man?
How dost thou good Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I ever told ye, This Man was never Cur'd, I see it too plain now; How do you feel your self? you look not perfect: How dull his eyes hangs?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: That may be discontent.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Believe me Friend, I would not suffer now the tithe of those paines this Man feels; mark his Forehead; What a cloud of cold dew hangs upon't?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I have it, again I have it; How it grows upon me? a miserable Man I am.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, A miserable Man thou shalt be; this is the tamest Trout I ever tickell'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: This way he went.

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: Pray heaven we find him living,
He's a brave Fellow, 'tis pitty he should perish thus.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
