sp.l: A strong hearted man, and of a notable sufferance.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: How now? how is it man?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Oh Gentlemen,
Never so sull of pain.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Did I not tell ye?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Never so full of pain Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: He is here;
How do you Sir?

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: Be of good comfort Souldier,
The Prince has sent us to you.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Do you think I may live?

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: He alters hourely, strangely.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: Yes you 〈◊〉 live: but—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Finely butted Doctor.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Do not discourage him.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: He must be told truth,
'Tis now too late to trifle.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Here the Prince comes.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How now Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Bewailing Sir a Souldier,
And one I think, your Grace will grieve to part with,
But every living thing—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis true, must perish,
Our lives are but our Martches to our Graves,
How dost thou now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Faith 'tis true Sir, we are but spans, and candles ends.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He's finely mortified.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Thou art heart whole yet; I see he alters strangely, and that apace too; I saw it this morning in him, when he poor Man I dare swear—

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: No beleev't, Sir, I never felt it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Here lies the pain now: How he is swell'd?

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.p: The Imposthume, fed with a new malignant Humour now, will grow to such a bigness, 'tis incredible, the compass of a Bushel will not hold it, and with such a Hell of torture it will rise too—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Can you endure me touch it?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Oh, I beseech you Sir:
I feel you sensibly e're you come near me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: He is finely wrought, he must be cut, no cure else,
And suddenly, you see how fast he blowes out.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Good Master Doctor, let me be beholding to you, I feel I cannot last.

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: For what Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: But ev'n for half a dozen Cans of good Wine,
That I may drink my Will out: I faint hideously.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Fetch him some Wine; and since he must go Gentlemen.
Why let him take his journey Merrily.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: That's ev'n the nearest way.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I could Laugh dead now.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Here, off with that.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: These two I give your Grace, a poor remembrance of a dying Man
Sir, and I beseech you wear 'em out,

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will Souldier, these are fine Legacies.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Among the Gentlemen, even all I have left; I am a poor Man, naked, yet something for remembrance: four a peece, Gentlemen, and so my Body where you please.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It will work.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I make your Grace my Executor, and I beseech ye
See my poor Will fulfill'd: sure I shall walk else.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: As full as they can be fill'd, here's my hand, Souldier.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: The Wine will tickle him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I would hear a Drum beat, but to see how I could endure it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Beat a Drum there.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: O Heavenly Musick, I would hear one Sing to't,
I am very full of pain.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Sing? 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Why, then I would drink a Drum full. Where lies the Enemy?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Why, here close by.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now he begins to 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And dare ye sight?
Dare ye fight Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.p: You must not cut him: he's gone then in a moment; all the hope left, is to work his weakness into sudden anger, and make him raise his passion above his pain, and so dispose him on the Enemy; his body then, being stirr'd with violence, will purge it self, and break the sore.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis true, Sir,

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: And then my Life for his.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I will not die thus.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: But he is too weak to doe—

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Dye like a Dog?

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: I, he's weak, but yet he's heart-whole.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: An excellent sign.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Hem.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Stronger still, and better.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Hem, hem; ran, tan, tan, tan.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: How he's i'th' way on't.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Well go thy ways, thou wilt do something certain.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And some brave thing, or let mine Eares be cut off. He's sinely wrought.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Let's after him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I pray Sir; But how Rogue, when this Cloud's melted in him, and all discover'd—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: That's for an after Mirth, away, away, away.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Let no man fear to dye: we love to sleep all,
And death is but the sounder sleep; all ages,
And all hours call us; 'tis so common, easie,
That little children tread those paths before us;
We are not sick, nor our souls prest with sorrows,
Nor go we out like tedious tales, forgotten;
High high we come, and hearty to our funerals,
And as the Sun that sets, in blood let's fall.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: 'Tis true, they have us fast, we cannot scape 'em,
Nor keeps the brow of fortune one smile for us,
Dishonourable ends we can scape though,
And (worse then those captivities) we can dye,
And dying nobly, though we leave behind us
These clods of flesh, that are too massie burthens,
Our living souls flie crown'd with living conquests

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: They have begun, fight bravely, and fall bravely;
And may that man that seeks to save his life now
By price, or promise, or by fear falls from us,
Never again be blest with name of Souldier.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: How now? who charged first? I seek a brave hand to set me off in death.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: We are not charg'd Sir, the Prince lies still.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: How comes this Larum up then?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: There is one desperate fellow, with the devil in him
(He never durst do this else) has broke into us,
And here he bangs ye two or three before him,
There five or six; ventures upon whole companies.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: And is not seconded?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Not a man follows.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Nor cut a peeces?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Their wonder yet has staid 'em.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Let's in, and see this miracle?

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: I admire it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Fetch him off, fetch him off, I am sure he's clouted;
Did I not tell you how 'twould take?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis admirable.
sp.stage: Enter Lieutenant with colours in his hand, pursuing 3 or 4 Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Follow that blow, my friend, there's at your coxcombs,
I fight to save me from the Surgeons miseries.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How the knave curries 'em

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: You cannot rogues,
Till you have my diseases, flie my furie,
Ye bread and butter rogues, do ye run from me?
And my side would give me leave, I would so hunt ye,
Ye porredge-gutted slaves, ye veale-broth boobies.
sp.stage: Enter Demetrius, and Physitians, and Gent.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Enough, enough Lieutenant, thou hast done bravely.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Mirrour of man.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: There's a flag for ye Sir,
I took it out o'th' shop, and never paid for't,
I'll to 'em again, I am not come to th' text yet.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: No more my souldier: beshrew my heart he is hurt sore.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hang him, he'll lick all those whole.

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: Now will we take him,
And cure him in a trice.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Be careful of him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Let me live but two years,
And do what ye will with me;
I never had but two hours yet of happiness;
Pray ye give me nothing to provoke my valour,
For I am ev'n as weary of this fighting—

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: Ye shall have nothing; come to the Princes Tent
And there the Surgeons presently shall search ye,
Then to your. rest.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: A little hansome litter
To lay me in, and I shall sleep.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Look to him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I do believe a Horse begot this Fellow,
He never knew his strength yet; they are our own.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I think so, I am cozen'd else; I would but see now
A way to fetch these off, and save their honours.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Only their lives.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Pray ye take no way of Peace now,
Unless it be with infinite advantage.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l:
I shall be rul'd;
Enter Trumpet and Herold.
Let the Battels now move forward,
Our self will give the Signal:
Now Herold, What's your Message?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: From my Masters
This honourable courtesie, a Parley
For half an hour, no more Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Let 'em come on,
They have my Princely word.
sp.stage: Enter Seleucus, Lysimachus, Ptolomy, Attendants, Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: They are here to attend ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Now Princes, your demands?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Peace, if it may be
Without the too much tainture of our honour:
Peace, and wee'l buy it too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: At what price?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Tribute.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: At all the charge of this War.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That will not do.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Leontius, you and I have serv'd together,
And run through many a Fortune with our Swords
Brothers in wounds, and health; one Meat has fed us,
One tent a thousand times from cold night cover'd us:
Our loves have been but one; and had we died then,
One Monument had held our Names, and Actions:
Why do you set upon your Friends such Prizes?
And Sacrifice to giddy chance such Trophies?
Have we forgot to dye? or are our Vertues
Less in Afflictions constant, than our Fortunes?
Ye are deceiv'd old Soldier.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know your worths,
And thus low bow in reverence to your Vertues:
Were these my Wars, or lead my power in chief here,
I knew then how to meet your Memories:
They are my Kings imployments; this Man sights now
To whom I owe all duty, faith, and service;
This man that fled before ye; call back that,
That bloody day again, call that disgrace home,
And then an easiy peace, may sheath our swords up.
I am not greedy of your lives and fortunes,
Nor do I gape ungratefully to swallow ye,
Honour the spur of all illustrious natures,
That made you famous Souldiers, and next Kings,
And not ambitious envy strikes me forward,
Will ye unarm, and yield your selves his prisoners?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: We never knew what that sound ment: no gives
Shall ever bind this body, but embraces;
Nor weight of sorrow here, till earth fall on me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Expect our charge then.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: 'Tis the nobler courtesie:
And so we leave the hand of heaven to bless us.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Stay, have you any hope?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: We have none left us,
But that one comfort of our deaths together;
Give us but room to fight.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Win it, and wear it.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: Call from the hills those companies hang ore us
Like bursting clouds; and then break in, and take us.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Find such a Souldier will forsake advantage,
And we'll draw off, to shew I dare be noble,
And hang a light out to ye in this darkness,
The light of peace; give up those Cities, forts,
And all those frontire Countryes to our uses.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Is this the peace? traitours to those that feed us,
Our Gods and people? give our Countryes from us?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Begin the knell, it sounds a great deal sweeter.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: Let loose your servant death.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Fall fate upon us,
Our memories shall never stink behind us.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Seleucus, great Selcucus.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: The Prince calls Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou stock of nobleness, and curtesie,
Thou father of the War—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What means the Prince now?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Give me my Standard here.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: His angers melted.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You Gentlemen that were his Prisoners,
And felt the bounty of that noble nature,
Lay all your hands, and bear these Colours to him,
The Standard of the Kingdom; take it Soldier.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: What will this mean?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou hast won it, bear it off,
And draw thy Men home whilst we wait upon thee.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You shall have all our Countries.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Ptol. All by Heaven Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will not have a Stone, a Brush, a Bramble,
No, in the way of curtesie, I'll start ye;
Draw off, and make a Lane through all the Army,
That these that have subdu'd us, may March through us.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sir, do not make me surset with such goodness,
I'll bear your Standard for ye; follow ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I Swear it shall be so, March through me fairly,
And thine be this days honour, great Seleucus.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: Mirrour of noble Minds.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Nay then ye hate me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I cannot speak now: Ex. with Drums and Shouts.
Well, go thy wayes, at a sure piece of bravery
Thou art the best, these Men are won by th' necks now:
I'll send a Post away.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: NO aptness in her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Not an immodest motion,
And yet she is as free, and when she is courted,
Makes as wild witty answers.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This more fires me, I must not have her thus.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: We cannot alter her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Have you put the youths upon her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: All that know any thing,
And have been studied how to catch a Beauty,
But like so many Whelps about an Elephant—
The Prince is coming home Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I hear that too,
But that's no matter; Am I alter'd well?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Not to be known I think Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must see her.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I offer'd all I had, all I could think of,
〈◊〉 her through all the points o'th' Compass, I think.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: She studies to undo the Court, to plant here
The enemy to our Age, Chastity?
She is the first, that e're bauked a close Arbour,
And the sweet contents within: She hates curl'd heads too,
And setting up of Beards she swears is Idolatry.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: I never knew so fair a Face so froze;
Yet she would make one think—

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: True by her carriage, for she's as wanton as a kid to th' out side, as full of mocks and taunts: I kiss'd her hand too, walkt with her half an hour.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: She heard me sing,
But still, when any hopes was, as 'tis her trick
To minister enough of those, then presently
With some new 〈◊〉 or other, nothing to th' matter,
And such a frown, as would sink all before her,
She takes her chamber; come we shall not be the last fools.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Not by a hundred I hope; 'tis a strange wench.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This 〈◊〉 me up still higher.
sp.stage: Enter Celia, and Ladies behind her.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Here she comes Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then be you gone: and take the women with ye,
And lay those Jewels in her way.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If I stay longer
How they flock after me? upon my conscience,
I have had a dozen horses given me this morning,
I'll ev'n set up a troop, and turn she souldier,
A good discreet wench now, that were not hidebound
Might raise a fine estate here, and suddenly:
For these warm things will give their souls—I can go no where
Without a world of offering to my excellence:
I am a Queen, a Goddess, I know not what—
And no constellation in all heaven, but I outshine it;
And they have found out now I have no eyes
Of mortal lights, but certaine influences,
Strange vertuous lightnings, humane nature starts at,
And I can kill my twenty in a morning,
With as much ease now—
Ha? what are these; new projects?
Where are my honourable Ladies? Are you out too?
Nay then I must buy the Stock, send me good carding;
I hope the Princes hand, be not in this sport;
I have not seen him yet, cannot hear from him,
And that, that troubles me: all these were recreations,
Had I but his sweet company to Laugh with me:
What Fellow's that? Another Apparition?
This is the 〈◊〉 Age: I should know that face,
Sure I have seen't before, not long since neither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She sees me now: O 〈◊〉 , a most rare creature!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis the same: I will take no notice of ye,
But if I do not sit ye, let me fry for't;
Is all this Cackling for your egg; they are fair ones,
Excellent rich no doubt too; and may stumble
A good staid mind, but I can go thus by 'em;
My honest friend, do you set off these Jewels?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Set 'em off, Lady?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I mean, sell 'em here, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She's very quick: for sale they are not meant sure.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: For sanctity I think much less: good ev'n Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay noble Lady, stay: 'tis you must wear 'em:
Never look strange, they are worthy your best beauty.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Did you speak to me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To you or to none living:
To you they are sent, to you they are sacrificed.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I'll never look a Horse i'th' mouth that's given:
I thank ye, Sir: I'll send one to reward ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do you never ask who sent 'em?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Never I:
Nor never care, if it be an honest end,
That end's the full reward, and thanks but slubber it;
If it be ill, I will not urge the acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This has a soul indeed: pray let me tell ye—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I care not if ye do, so you do it hansomly,
And not stand picking of your words.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The King sent 'em.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.p: Away, away, thou art some foolish fellow, and now I think thou hast stole 'em too; the King sent 'em? Alas good man, wouldst thou make me believe he has nothing to do with things of these worths, but wantonly to fling 'em? he's an old man, a good old man, they say too: I dare swear full many a year ago he left these gambols: here, take your trinkets.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sure I do not lye, Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I know thou lyest extreamly, damnably:
Thou hast a lying face.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I was never thus ratled.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But say I should believe: why are these sent me?
And why art thou the Messenger? who art thou?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lady, look on 'em wisely, and then consider who can send such as these, but a King only? and, to what beauty can they be oblations, but only yours? For me that am the carrier, 'tis only sit you know I am his servant, and have fulfil'd his will

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You are short and pithy;
What must my beauty do for these?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sweet Lady, you cannot be so hard of understanding, when a King's favour shines upon ye gloriously, and speaks his love in these—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
O then love's the matter; Sir reverence love: now I begin to feel ye: and I should be the Kings Whore, a brave title: and go as glorious as
the Sun, O brave still: the chief Commandress of his Concubines, hurried from place to place to meet his pleasures.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A deyilish subt il wench, but a rare spirit.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: And when the good old spunge has suckt my youth dry, and left some of his Royal aches i' my bones: when time shall tell me I have plough'd my life up, and cast long furrows in my face to 〈◊〉 me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You must not think so, Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Then can these, Sir,
These precious things, the price of youth and beauty;
This shop here of sin-offerings set me off again?
Can it restore me chaste, young, innocent?
Purge me to what I was? add to my memory
An honest and a noble fame? The Kings device?
The sin's as universal as the Sun is,
And lights an everlasting Torch to shame me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do you hold so slight account of a great Kings 〈◊〉 ,
That all knees bow to purchase?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Prethee peace: If thou knewst how ill favouredly thy tale becomes thee, and what ill root it takes—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You would be wiser.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Could the King sind no shape to shift his pander into,
But reverend Age? and one so like himself too?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She has found me out.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Cozen the world with gravity?
Prethee resolve me one thing, do's the King love thee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I think he do's.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: It seems so by thy Office: he loves thy use, and when that's ended, hates thee: thou seemest to me a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, I am one.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And hast fought for thy Country?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Many a time.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: May be, commanded too?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have done, Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O wretched man, below the state of pity!
Canst thou forget thou wert begot in honour?
A sree Companion for a King? a Souldier?
Whose Nobleness dare feel no want, but Enemies?
〈◊〉 thou forget this, and decline so wretchedly,
To eat the Bread of Bawdry, of base Bawdry?
〈◊〉 on the 〈◊〉 of 〈◊〉 ? fling thy Sword from thee?
Dishonour to the noble name that nursed thee?
Go, beg diseases: let them be thy Armour's,
Thy sights, the flames of Lust, and their foul issues.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why then I am a King, and mine own Speaker.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
And I as free as you, mine own Disposer: There, take your Jewels; let them give them lustres that have dark Lives and Souls; wear 'em your
self, Sir, you'l seem a Devil else.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I command ye stay.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Be just, I am commanded.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will not wrong ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Then thus low falls my duty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can ye love me? say I, and all I have—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I cannot love ye; without the 〈◊〉 of faith I cannot hear ye; ye hand upon my love, like frosts on Lilies: I can dye, but I cannot love: you are answer'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must find apter means, I love her truly.

div.head: Scaene 2.
div.stage: Enter Demetr. Leon. Lieu. Gent. Sould. and Host.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Hither do you say she is come?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I am sure on't: for whilst I waited 'on ye, putting my Wife in trust, I know not by what means, but the King found her, and hither she was brought; how, or to what end—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My Father found her?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: So my Wife informs me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Leontius, pray draw off the Souldiers,
I would a while be private.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Fall off Gentlemen, the Prince would be alone.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Is he so cunning? there is some trick in this, and you must know it, and be an agent too: which if it prove so—

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Pull me to pieces, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My Father found her?
My Father brought her hither? went she willingly?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: My Wife says full of doubts.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I cannot blame her,
No more: there's no trust, no faith in mankind.
sp.stage: Enter Antigonus, Menippus, Leontius, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Keep her up close, he must not come to see her:
You are welcome nobly now, welcome home Gentlemen;
You have done a courteour service on the Enemy
Has tyed his Faith for ever; you shall find it;
Ye are not now in's debt Son: still your sad looks?
Leontius, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Truth Sir, I know not.
We have been merry since we went.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I feel it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come, what's the matter now? do you want money?
Sure he has heard o'th' wench.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is that a want, Sir?
I would fain speak to your Grace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You may do freely.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And not deserve your anger?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That you may too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: There was a Gentlewoman, and sometime my prisoner,
Which I thought well of Sir: your Grace conceives me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I do indeed, and with much grief conceive ye; with full as much grief as your Mother bare you. There was such a Woman: would I might as well say, there was no such, Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: She was vertuous, and therefore not unfit my youth to love her: she was as fair—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Her beauty I'll proclaim too, to be as rich as ever raign'd in Woman; but how she made that good, the Devil knows.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: She was—O Heaven!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The Hell to all thy glories,
Swallow'd thy youth, made Shipwrack of thine honour: she was a Devil.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye are my Father, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And since ye take a pride to shew your follies,
I'll muster 'em, and all the World shall view 'em.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What heat is this? the Kings eyes speak his Anger.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou hast abus'd thy youth, drawn to thy Fellowship, instead of Arts and Arms, a Womans kisses, the subtilties, and soft heats of a Harlot.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Good Sir, mistake her not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A Witch, a Sorceress:
I tell thee but the truth; and hear Demetrius,
Which has so dealt upon thy blood with charms,
Devilish and dark; so lockt up all thy Vertues;
So pluckt thee back from what thou sprungst from, glorious.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O Heaven, that any tongue but his durst say this!
That any heart durst harbour it! Dread Father,
If for the innocent the gods allow us
To bend our knees—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Away, thou art bewitch'd still;
Though she be dead, her power still lives upon thee.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Dead? O sacred Sir: Dead did you say?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She is dead, fool.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: It is not possible: be not so angry,
Say she is faln under your sad displeasure,
Or any thing but dead, say she is banished,
Invent a crime, and I'll believe it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dead by the Law: we found her Hell, and her,
I mean her Charms and Spells, for which she perish'd,
And she confest she drew thee to thy ruine,
And purpos'd it, purpos'd my Empires overthrow.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: But is she dead? Was there no pity Sir?
If her youth err'd, Was there no mercy shown her?
Did 〈◊〉 look on her Face, when ye Condemn'd her?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I look'd into her heart, and there she was hideous.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Can she be dead? Can vertue fall untimely?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She is dead, deservingly she died.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I have done then. O matchless sweetness, whither art thou vanished? O thou fair soul of all thy Sex, what Paradise hast thou inrich'd and blest? I am your Son, Sir, and to all you shall command stand most obedient; only a little time I must intreat you to study to forget her; 'twill not be long, Sir, nor I long after it: Art thou dead Celia? Dead my poor Wench? my joy, pluckt green with violence: O fair sweet flower, farewell? Come thou destroyer Sorrow, thou melter of the Soul, dwell with me; dwell with me solitary thoughts, tears, cryings, nothing that loves the day, love me, or seek me, nothing that loves its own life haunt about me: and Love, I charge thee, never charm mine eyes more, nor ne're betray a Beauty to my curses: for I shall curse all now, hate all, forswear all, and all the brood of fruitful nature yex at, for she is gone that was all, and I nothing—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This opinion must be maintain'd.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It shall be, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let him go; I can at mine own pleasure draw him to th' right again: wait your Instructions, and see the Souldier paid Leontius: once more ye are wellcome all.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Health to your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou wentest along the journey, How canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I did, but I am sure 'tis so: had I 〈◊〉 behind,
I think this had not proved.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A Wench the reason?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Who's that talks of a Wench there?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All this discontent
About a Wench?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Where is this Wench; good Colonel?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Prithee hold thy Peace: Who calls thee to Counsel?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Why, if there be a Wench—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l:
'Tis sit thou know her:
Enter 2 Gentlemen.
That I'll say for thee, and as fit thou art for her,
Let her be mew'd or stopt: How is it Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: He's wondrous discontent, he'll speak to no Man.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: H'has taken his Chamber close, admits no entrance;
Tears in his eyes, and cryings out.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: 'Tis so, Sir,
And now I wish my self half hang'd e're I went this journey.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What is this Woman?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I cannot tell ye,
But handsome as Heaven.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: She is not so high I hope, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I, that would be known.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: VVhy, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I cannot show ye neither;
The King has now dispos'd of her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There lies the matter:
VVill he admit none to come to comfort him?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Not any near, nor, let 'em knock their hearts out,
VVill never speak.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: 'Tis the best way if he have her;
For look you, a Man would be loth to be disturb'd in's pastime;
'Tis every good Man's case.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis all thy Living, we must not suffer this, we dare not suffer it: for when these tender Souls meet deep 〈◊〉 , they are not strong enough to struggle with 'em, but drop away as Snow does, from a Mountain, and in the torrent of their own sighs sink themselves: I will, and must speak to him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: So must I too:
He promis'd me a charge.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Of what? of Children
Upon my Conscience, thou hast a double company,
And all of thy own 〈◊◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: That's all one, I'll raise 'em to a Regiment, und then command 'em, when they turn disobedient, unbeget 'em: knock 'em o'th' head, and put in new.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A rare way; but for all this, thou art not valiant enough to dare to see the Prince now?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Do ye think he's angry?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Extreamly vext.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: To the endangering of any Man 〈◊〉 near him.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Yet, if thou couldst but win him out, what e're thy suit were, believe it granted presently.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yet thou must think though,
That in the doing he may break upon ye,
And—

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: If he do not kill me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There's the question.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: For half a dozen hurts.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Art thou so valiant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Not absolutely so neither: no it cannot be, I want my Impostumes, and my things about mt, yet I'll make danger, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Till be rare sport, howe'r it take; give me thy hand; if thou dost this, I'll raise thee up a Horse Troop, take my word for't.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: VVhat may be done by humane Man.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let's go then.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Away before he cool: he will relapse else.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: VVill she not yield?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: For all we can urge to her;
I swore you would Marry her, she laugh'd extreamly,
And then she rail'd like Thunder.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Call in the Magician. Enter Magician with a Bowl.
I must, and will obtain her, I am ashes else.
Are all the Philters in? Charms, Powder, Roots?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: They are all in; and now I only stay
The Invocation of some helping Spirits.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To your work then, and dispatch.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Sit still, and fear not.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I shall ne'r 〈◊〉 these sights.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Away with the VVoman: go wait without.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: VVhen the Devil's gone, pray call me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Be sure you make it powerful enough.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Pray doubt not—He Conjures.

lg.head: A SONG.
lg.l: RIse from the Shades below,
All you that prove
The helps of looser Love;
Rise and beslow
Vpon this Cup, whatever may compel
By powerful Charm, and unresisted Spell.
A Heart un-warm'd to melt in Loves desires,
Distill into this Liquor all your fires:
Heats, longings, tears,
But keep back frozen fears;
That she may know, that has 〈◊〉 power desy'd,
Art is a power that will not be deny'd.

lg.head: The ANSVVER.
lg.l: I Obey, I Obey,
And am come to view the 〈◊〉 ,
Brought along, all may 〈◊〉 ,
All the Earth has, and our 〈◊〉 :
Here's a little, little Flower,
This will make her sweat an hour,
Then unto such slames arise,
A thousand joys will not suffice.
Here's the powder of the Moon,
With which she caught Endymion;
The powerful Tears that Venus cry'd,
When the Boy Adonis dy'd
Here's Medea's Charm, with which
Jason's heart she did bewitch,
Omphale this Spell put in,
When she made the Libyan spin.

This dull root pluckt from Lethe
〈◊〉 ,
Purges all pure thoughts, and good.
These I 〈◊〉 thus, round, round, round,
Whilst our light feet beat the ground.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Now Sir, 'tis full, and whosoever drinks this
Shall violently 〈◊〉 upon your Person,
And never 〈◊◊〉 eat 〈◊〉 :
And those expir'd, 'tis done. You have my art, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: See him rewarded liberally—Leucippe,
Here, take this Bowl, and when she calls for Wine next,
Be sure you give her this, and see her drink it;
Delay no time when she calls next.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I shall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let none else touch it on your life.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I am charg'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now if she have an Antidote Art, let her 'scape me.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: There's the Door, Lieutenant, if you dare do any thing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Here's no man waits.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: H'as given a charge that none shall,
Nor none shall come within the hearing of him:
Dare ye go forward?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Let me put on my Skull first.
My head's almost beaten into th' pap of an Apple.
Are there no Guns i'th door?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The Rogue will do it.
And yet I know he has no 〈◊〉 to't.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: What 〈◊◊〉 when I knock, for stones,
For those may pepper 〈◊◊◊〉 none.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How he 〈◊◊◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: If I be 〈1 line〉

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 〈1 line〉 .

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Away, 〈◊◊◊〉 that then? I'll knock softly.
Pray heaven he speaks in a low voice now to comfort me:
I feel I have no heart to't:—Is't well, Gentlemen?
Colonel, my Troop—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A little 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Stay, stay;
Here is a window, I will see, stand wide.
By—he's charging of a Gun.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There's no such matter.
There's no body in this room.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: O'twas a fire-shovel:
Now I'll knock louder; if he say who's there?
As sure he has so much manners, then will I answer him
So finely and demurely; my Troop Colonel—

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Knock louder, Fool, he hears not.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: You fool, do you.
Do and you dare now.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I do not undertake it.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Then hold your peace, and mddle with your own matters.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now he will knock.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, will't please you hear Sir? your Grace, I'll look again, what's that?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: He's there now. Lord! How he stares! I ne'r yet saw him thus, alter'd: Stand now, and take the Troop.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Would I were in't, and a good horse under me: I must knock again, the Devil's at my fingers ends: He comes now. Now Colonel, if I live—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The Troop's thine own Boy.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What desperate fool, ambitious of his ruine?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Your Father, would desire ye, Sir, to come to dinner.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou art no more.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Now, now, now, now.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Poor Coxcomb: why do I aim at thee?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: His fear 〈◊〉 kill'd him.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I protest he's almost stiff: bend him and rub him, hold his Nose close, you if you be a woman, help us a little: here's a man near perish'd.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Alas alas, I have nothing here about me. Look to my Bowl; I'll run in presently and fetch some waters: bend him, and set him upwards.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A goodly man—Here's a brave heart: he's warm again: you shall not leave us i'th' 〈◊〉 so, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Now he breaths too.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: If we had but any drink to raise his Spirits. What's that i'th' Bowl? upon my life, good Liquor, she would not own it else.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: He sees.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Look up Boy. And take this Cup, and drink it off; I'll pledge thee. Guide it to his mouth, he swallows heartily.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Oh! fear and sorrow's dry; 'tis off—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Stand up man.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Am I not shot?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A way with him, and chear him: thou hast won thy Troop.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I think I won it bravely.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Go, I must see the Prince, he must not live thus; and let me hear an hour hence from ye. Well Sir—

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Here, here: where's the sick Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He's up, and gone, Lady.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Alas, that I came so late.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He must still thank ye; ye left that in a Cup here did him comfort.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: That in the Bowl?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes truly, very much comfort, he drank it off, and after it spoke lustily.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Did he drink it all?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All off.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: The Devil choak him; I am undone: h'as twenty Devils in him; undone for ever, left he none?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I think not.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: No, not a drop: what shall become of me now? had he no where else to swound? a vengeance swound him: Undone, undone, undone: stay, I can lye yet and swear too at a pinch, that's all my comfort. Look to him; I say look to him, and but mark what follows.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What a Devil ails the Woman? here comes the Prince again, with such a sadness on his sace, as sorrow, sorrow her self but poorly imitates. Sorrow of Sorrows on that heart that caus'd it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why might she not be false and treacherous to me? and found so by my Father? she was a Woman, and many a one of that Sex, young and fair, as full of faith as she, have fallen, and foully.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It is a Wench! O that I knew the circumstance.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why might not, to preserve me from this ruine, she having lost her honour, and abused me, my father change the forms o'th' coins, and execute his anger on a falt she ne'r committed, only to keep me safe? why should I think so? She never was to me, but all obedience, sweetness and love.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: How heartily he weeps now? I have not wept this thirty years, and upward; but now, if I should be hang'd I cannot hold from't: It grieves me to the heart.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Who's that that mocks me?

sp.p: A plague of him that mocks ye: I grieve truly, truly, and heartily to 〈◊〉 you thus, Sir: and if it lay in my power, gods are my witness, who e'r he be that took your sweet peace from you; I am not so old yet, nor want I spirit—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: No more of that, no more Leonitus, revenges are the gods: our part is sufferance: farewel, I shall not see thee long.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Good Sir, tell me the cause, I know there is a woman in't; do you hold me faithful? dare you trust your Souldier? sweet Prince, the cause?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I must not, dare not tell it, and as thou art an honest man, enquire not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Will ye be merry then?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I am, wondrous 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis wondrous well: you think now this becomes ye. Shame on't, it does not, Sir, it shews not handsomely; If I were thus; you would swear I were an Ass straight; a wooden ass; whine for a Wench?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prithee leave me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will not leave ye for a tit.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Leontius!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: For that you may have any where for six pence, and a dear penny worth too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Nay, then you are troublesome.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Not half so troublesome as you are to your self, Sir; was that brave 〈◊〉 made to pant for a placket: and now i'th' dog-days too, when nothing dare love! That noble Mind to melt away and moulder for a hey nonny, nonny! Would I had a Glass here, to shew ye what a pretty toy ye are turn'd to.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My wretched Fortune.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Will ye but let me know her? I'll once turn Bawd: go to, they are good mens offices, and not so contemptible as we take 'em for: and if she be above ground, and a Woman; I ask no more; I'll bring her o' my back, Sir, By this hand I will, and I had as lieve bring the Devil, I care not who she be, nor where I have her; and in your arms, or the next Bed deliver her, which you think fittest, and when you have danc'd your galliard.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Away, and fool to them are so affected: O thou art gone, and all my comfort with thee! Wilt thou do one thing for me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All things i'th' World, Sir, of all dangers.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Swear.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come near me no more then

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come no more near me: thou art a plague-sore to me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Give you good ev'n Sir; If you be suffer'd thus, we shall have 〈◊〉 sport. I will be sorry yet.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: How now, how does he?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nay, if I tell ye, hang me, or any man else that hath his nineteen wits; he has the bots I think, he groans, and roars, and kicks.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Will he speak yet?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Not willingly: shortly he will not see a man; if ever I look'd upon a Prince so metamorphos'd, so juggl'd into I know not what, shame take me; this 'tis to be in love

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Is that the cause on't?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What is it not the cause of but bear-baitings? And yet it stinks much like it: out upon't; what giants, and what dwarffs what owls and apes, what dogs, and cats it makes us? men that are possest with it, live as if they had a Legion of Devils in 'em, and every Devil of a several nature; nothing but Hey-pass,, re-pass: where's the Lieutenant? Has he gather'd up the end on's wits again?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: He is alive: but you that talk of wonders, shew me but such a wonder as he is now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why, he was ever at the worst a wonder.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: He is now most wonderful; a Blazer now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What ails the Fool? and what Star reigns now Gentlemen we have such Prodigies?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: 'Twill pose your heaven-hunters; he talks now of the King, no other language, and with the King as he imagines, hourly. Courts the King, drinks to the King, dies for the King, buys all the Pictures of the King, wears the Kings colours.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Does he not lye i'th' King street too?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: He's going thither, makes prayers for the King in sundry languages, turns all his Proclamations into metre; is really in love with the King, most dotingly, and swears Adonis was a Devil to him: A sweet King, a most comely King, and such a King—

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Then down on's murrow-bones; O excellent King, thus he begins, Thou Light, and Life of Creatures, Angel-ey'd King, vouchsafe at length thy favour; and so proceeds to incision: what thinst ye of this sorrow?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Will as familiarly kiss the Kings horses as they pass by him: ready to ravish his footmen.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why, this is above Ela? but how comes this?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Nay that's to understand yet, but thus it is, and this part but the poorest, 'twould make a man leap over the Moon to see him act these.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: With sighs as though his heart would break: cry like a breech'd boy, not eat a bit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I must go see him presently, for this is such a gig, for certain Gentlemen, the Fiend rides on a Fiddle-stick.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: I think so.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Can ye guide me to him for half an hour? I am his to see the miracle.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: We sure shall start him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are you sure she drank it?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Now must I lye most considently. Yes Sir, she has drunk it off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How works it with her?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I see no alteration yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: There will be, for he is the greatest Artist living made it. Where is she now?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: She is ready to walk out, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stark mad, I know she will be.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: So I hope, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She knows not of the Prince?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Of no man living—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How do I look! how do my cloaths become me? I am not very grey.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: A very youth, Sir, upon my maiden-head as 〈◊〉 as April: heaven bless that sweet face, 'twill undo a thousand; many a soft heart must sob yet, 〈◊〉 that wither, your Grace can give content enough.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I think so.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Here she comes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How shall I keep her off me? go, and perfume the room: make all things ready.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: No hope yet of the Prince! no comfort of him! they keep me mew'd up here, as they mew mad folks, no company but my afflictions. This royal Devil again! strange, how he hants me! how like a poyson'd potion his eyes fright me! has made himself handsome-too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do you look now, Lady? you will leap anon.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Cnrl'd and Perfum'd? I smell him; he looks on's Legs too, sure he will cut a Caper; God a Mercy dear December.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O do you smile now; I knew it would work with you; come hither pretty one.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I like those Court'sies well; come hither and kiss me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I am reading, Sir, of a short Treatise here, that's call'd the Vanity of 〈◊〉 : Has your Grace seen it? He says here, that an Old Man's loose desire, 〈◊〉 like the Glow-worms light, the Apes so wondr'd at: which, when they gather'd Sticks, and laid upon't, and blew, and blew, turn'd Tail, and went out presently: And in another place he calls their Loves, 〈◊〉 smells of dying Flowers, carry no comforts; they'r doting, stinking Foggs, so thick and muddy, 〈◊〉 with all his beams cannot beat through 'em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How's this? 〈◊◊〉 the 〈◊〉 ? you but foole still I know you love me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: As you are just and honest? I know I love and honour you: admire you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This makes against me, fearfully against me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
But as you bring your power to 〈◊〉 me, your Traps to catch mine 〈◊〉 to 〈◊◊〉 ; as you 〈◊〉 out your 〈◊〉 to overwhelm me, Hell never haved good, as I 〈◊〉 you, Sir; and I dare tell it to your Face: What
glory now, after all your Conquests got, your Titles, the ever-living Memories rais'd to you; Can my defeat be? my poor 〈◊〉 , What triumph? and when you crown your swelling Cups to Fortune, What honourable Tongue can sing my Story? Be as your Emblem is, a glorious Lamp set on the top of all, to light all perfectly: Be as your office is, a god-like Justice, into all shedding equally your Vertues.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: She has drencht me now; now I admire her goodness; so young, so nobly strong, I never tasted: Can nothing in the power of Kings perswade ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, nor that power command me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Say I should force ye? I have it in my will.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Your Will's a poor one; and though it be a King's Will, a despised one. Weaker than Infants legs, your Will's in Swadling-Clouts; a thousand ways my will has found to 〈◊〉 ye; a thousand doors to 'scape ye, I dare die, Sir; as suddenly 〈◊〉 die, as you can offer: Nay, say you had your Will, say you had ravish'd me, perform'd your lust, What had you purchas'd by it? What Honour won? Do you know who dwells above, Sir, And what they have prepar'd for Men turn'd Devils? Did you never hear their Thunder? start and tremble, Death sitting on your blood, when their sires visit us. VVill nothing wring you then do you think? sit hard here, and like a Snail curl round about 〈◊〉 Conscience, biting and stinging: VVill you not roar too late then? then when rou shake in horrour of this Villany, then will I rise a Star in Heaven, and scorn ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lust, how I hate thee now! and love this sweetness! VVill you be my Queen? Can that price purchase ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Not all the VVorld, I am a Queen already, Crown'd by his Love, I must not lose for Fortune; I can give none away, sell none away, Sir, can lend no love, am not mine own Exchequer; for in anothers heart my hope and peace lies.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Your fair hands, Lady? for yet I am not pure enough to touch these Lips, in that sweet Peace ye spoke of. Live now for ever, and I to serve your Vertues—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: VVhy now you show a god! now I kneel to ye: This Sacrifice of Virgins Joy send to ye: Thus I hold up my hands to Heaven that touch'd ye, and pray 〈◊〉 Blessings dwell about ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Vertue commands the Stars: rise more than Vertue; your present comfort shall be now my business.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: All my obedient service wait upon ye.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hast thou clean forgot the VVars?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: His mind's much elevated now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 〈1 line〉 .

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I am 〈◊◊〉 with this Fellow

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He will call me 〈◊〉 anon.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis ten to one else.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: O King that thou knew'st I lov'd thee, how I lov'd thee, and where, O King, I barrel up thy beauty.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He cannot leave his Sutlers trade, he VVoo's in't.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: O never, King.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By this hand, when I consider—

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: My honest friend, you are a little sawcy.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I told you you would have it.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: VVhen mine own worth—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is flung into the ballance, and found nothing.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And yet a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And yet a sawcy one.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: One that has followed thee.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Fair and far off.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Fought for thy Grace.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Twas for some 〈◊〉 , you lye Sir.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: He's the Son of a Whore denies this: VVill that satisfie ye?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Shall then that thing that honours thee? How miserable a thing soever, yet a thing still; And though a thing of nothing, thy thing ever.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Here's a new thing.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: He's in a deep 〈◊〉 now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I'll 〈◊〉 him our 〈◊〉 VVhen's the King's Birth-day?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: VVhen e're it be, 〈◊〉 day I'll dye with Ringing. And there's the resolution of a Lover.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A goodly resolution sure I take it. He is 〈◊〉 , or moop'd, or his brains 〈◊〉 , Could he find no body to fall in Love with but the King, the good old 〈◊〉 , to doat upon him too? Stay, now I remember, what the Fat Woman warn'd me, bad me remember, and look to him to: I'll hang if she have not a hand in this: he's conjur'd, go after him, I pity the poor Rascal; In the mean time I'll wait occasion to work upon the Prince.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Pray do that seriously.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: He's very ill.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I am very sorry for't, and much asham'd I have wrong'd his Innocence; Menippus, guide her to the Princes Lodgings, there leave her to his love again.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I am glad, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: He will speak to none.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O I shall break that silence; Be quick, take fair attendance.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Yes Sir presently.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He will find his Tongue, I warrant ye; his health too; (Exit.
I send a Physick will not fail.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Fair work it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We hear the Princes mean to visit us in way of truce.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: 'Tis thought so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come; let's in then, and think upon the noblest ways to meet em.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: There's no way now to get in: all the Light stopt too; nor can I hear a sound of him, pray Heaven he use no violence: I think he has more Soul, stronger, and I hope nobler: VVould I could but see once this Beaty he groans under, or come to know but any circumstance. What noise is that there? I think I heard him groan: here are some coming; a VVoman too, I'll stand aloof, and view 'em.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Well, some of you have been to blame in this point, but I forgive ye: The King might have pickt out too some sitter VVoman to have tri'd his Valour.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: 'Twas all to the best meant, Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I must think so, for how to mend it now: he's here you tell me.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: He's Madam, and the joy to see you only will draw him out.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I know that VVomans Tongue, I think I have seen her Face too: I'll go nearer: If this be she, he has some cause of Sorrow: 'Tis the same Face; the same, most excellent VVoman.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: This should be Lord Leontius: I remember him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Lady, I think ye know me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Speak soft, good Souldier:
I do, and know ye worthy, know ye Noble;
Know not me yet openly, as you love me;
But let me see ye again, I'll satisfie ye:
I am wondrous glad to see those eyes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You have charg'd me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You shall know where I am.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I will not off yet: She goes to knock at's Door: This must be she the 〈◊〉 told me of: right glad I am on't, he will bolt now for certain.
〈◊◊◊〉 Sir? I'll trouble ye no more: I thank your courtesie, 〈◊◊◊◊〉 .

sp.l: 〈◊◊◊〉 humble Servants.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: So now my 〈◊〉 are off: Pray Heaven he be here! Master, my Royal Sir Do 〈◊◊〉 who calls ye! Love, my Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 〈◊◊◊〉 Quail-pipes, the Cock will Crow anon.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 〈◊◊◊〉 , when I call at your VVindow?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I 〈◊〉 him stirring: now he comes wondring out.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 〈◊◊〉 sound sure: the sweetness of that Tongue draws all 〈◊〉 to it 〈◊◊〉 the shape too.

sp.l: How 〈◊◊〉 upon her?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 〈◊◊◊〉 eyes abuse me? 'tis she, the living Celia: your hand Lady?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: VVhat 〈◊〉 this mean?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: The very 〈◊〉 same Celia.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How do ye Sir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Only turn'd brave. I heard you were dead my dear one, compleat, She is wondrous brave, a wondrous Gallant Courtier.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How he surveys me round? Here has been foul play.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How came she thus?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: It was a kind of Death, Sir, I suffer'd in your absence, mew'd up here, and kept conceal'd I know not how.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 'Tis likely: How came you hither Celia? wondrous Gallant: Did my Father send for ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: So they told me, Sir, and on command too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I hope you were obedient?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I was so ever.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And ye were bravely us'd?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I wanted nothing: My Maiden-head to a mote i'th' Sun, he's jealous: I must now play the Knave with him, tho' I dye 〈◊〉 , 〈◊〉 in my nature.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Her very eyes are alter'd: Jewels, and rich ones too, I never saw yet— And what were those came for ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Monstrous Jealous: Have I liv'd at the rate of these scorn'd questions? they seem'd of good sort, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Kind Men?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
They were wondrous kind: I was much beholding to 'em; There was one
〈◊〉
Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l:
One
〈◊〉 , a notable merry Lord, and a good Companion.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l:
And one
〈◊〉
too?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yes, there was such a one.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And Timon.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis most true.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And thou most treacherous: my Fathers bawds by—they never miss course; and were these 〈◊〉 with ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Every hour Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And was there not a Lady, a fat Lady?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O yes; a notable good wench.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: The Devil fetch her.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis ev'n the merriest wench—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Did she keep with ye too?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: She was all in all; my bed fellow, eat with me, brought me acquainted.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You are well known here then?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There is no living here a stranger I think.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How came ye by this brave gown?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: This is a poor one: alas, I have twenty richer: do you see these jewels? why, they are the poorest things, to those are sent me, and sent me hourly too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is there no modestie? on faith in this fair Sex?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What will this prove too? for yet with all my wits, I understand not.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Come hither; thou art dead indeed, lost tainted; all that I left thee fair, and innocent, sweet as thy youth, and carrying comfort in't; all that I hoped for vertuous, is fled from thee, turn'd back, and bankrupt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By'r Lady, this cuts shrewdly.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Thou art dead, for ever dead; sins surfeit 〈◊〉 thee; the ambition of those wanton eyes betrai'd thee; go from me, grave of honour; go thou foul one, thou glory of thy sin; go thou despis'd one, and where there is no vertue, nor no virgin; where Chastity was never known, nor heard of; where nothing reigns but impious lust, and looser faces. Go thither, child of blood, and 〈◊〉 my doating.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You do not speak this seriously I hope Sir; I did but jest with you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Look not upon me, there is more hell in those eyes, than hell harbours; and when they flame, more torments.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Dare ye trust me? you durst once even with all you had: your love Sir? by this fair light I am honest.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Thou subtle Circe, cast not upon the maiden light eclipses: curse not the day.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Come, come, you shall not do this: how fain you would seem angry now, to fright me; you are not in the field among your Enemies; come, I must cool this courage.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Out thou impudence, thou ulcer of thy Sex; when I first saw thee, I drew into mine eyes mine own destruction, I pull'd into my heart that sudden poyson, that now consumes my dear content to cinders: I am not now Demetrius, thou hast chang'd me; thou woman, with thy thousand wiles hast chang'd me; thou Serpent with thy angel-eyes hast slain me; and where, before I touch'd on this fair ruine, I was a man, and reason made, and mov'd me, now one great lump of grief, I grow and wander.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And as you are noble, do you think I did this?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Put all the Devils wings on, and flie from me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I will go from ye, never more to see ye. I will flie from ye, as a plague hangs o're me; and through the progress of my life hereafter; where ever I shall sind a fool, a false man, one that ne're knew the worth of polish'd vertue; a base suspecter of a virgins honour, a child that flings away the wealth he cry'd for, him will I call Demetrius: that fool Demetrius, that mad man a Demetrius; and that false man, the Prince of broken faiths, even Prince Demetrius. You think now, I should cry, and kneel down to ye, petition for my peace; let those that feel here the weight of evil, wait for such a favour, I am above your hate, as far above it, in all the actions of an innocent life, as the pure Stars are from the muddy meteors, cry when you know your folly: howl and curse then, beat that unmanly breast, that holds a false heart, when ye shall come to know, whom ye have flung from ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Pray ye stay a little.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Not your hopes can alter me. Then let a thousand black thoughts muster in ye, and with those enter in a thousand doatings; those eyes be never shut, but drop to nothing: my innocence for ever haunt and fright ye: those arms together grow in folds; that tongue, that bold bad tongue that barks out these disgraces. When you shall come to know how nobly vertuous I have preserv'd my life, rot, rot within ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Live a lost man for ever. Go ask your Fathers conscience what I suffered, and through what seas of hazards I sayl'd through: mine honour still advanced in spight of tempests, then take your leave of love; and confess freely, you were never worthy of this heart that serv'd ye, and so farewel ungratefull—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is she gone?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I'le follow her, and will sind out this matter.—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Are ye pleas'd now? have you got your heart again? have I restor'd ye that?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Sir even for Heaven 〈◊〉 , and sacred truth 〈◊〉 , tell me how ye found her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will, and in few words. Before I try'd her, 'tis true, I thought her most unfit her fellowship, and fear'd her too: which fear begot that story I told ye first: but since, like gold I toucht her.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And how dear Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Heavens holy light's not purer: the constancy and goodness of all women that ever liv'd, to win the names of worthy, this noble Maid has doubled in her: honour, all promises of wealth, all art to win her, and by all tongues imploy'd, wrought as much on her as one may do upon the Sun at noon day by lighting Candles up: her shape is heavenly, and to that heavenly shape her thoughts are angels.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Why did you tell me Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I err'd in't: but since I made a full proof of her vertue, I find a King too poor a servant for her. Love her, and honour her; in all observe her. She must be something more than time yet tells her: and certain I believe him best, enjoyes her: I would not lose the hope of such a Daughter, to add another Empire to my honour.—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: O wretched state! to what end shall I turn me? and where begins my penance? now, what service will win her love again? my death must do it: and if that sacrifice can purge my follies, be pleas'd, O mighty Love, I dye thy servant—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I Know he do's not deserve ye; h'as us'd you poorly: and to redeem himself—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Redeem?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know it—there's no way left.

sp.speaker: Cel:
sp.p: For Heavens sake do not Name him, do not think on him, Sir, he's so far from me in all my thoughts now, methinks I never knew him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But yet I would see him again.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, never, never.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I do not mean to lend him any comfort; but to asslict him, so to torture him; that even his very Soul may shake within him; to make him know, though he be great and powerful, 'tis not within his aim to deal dishonourably, and carry it off, and with a Maid of your sort.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I must confess, I could most spightfully asslict him; now, now, I could whet my anger at him; now, arm'd with bitterness, I could shoot through him; I long to vex him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And do it home, and bravely.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Were I a Man?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I'll help that weakness in ye: I honour ye, and serve ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Not only to disclaim me, when he had seal'd his Vowes in Heaven, sworn to me, and poor believing I became his servant: but most maliciously to brand my Credit, stain my poor Name.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I would not suffer it: see him I would again, and to his teeth too: Od's precious, I would ring him such a Lesson—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have done that already.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing: It was too poor a purge; besides, by this time he has found his fault, and feels the Hells that follow it. That, and your urg'd on anger to the highest, why, 'twill be such a stroak—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Say he repent then, and seek with tears to soften, I am a Woman; a Woman that have lov'd him, Sir, have honour'd him: I am no more.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why, you may deal thereafter.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If I forgive him, I am lost.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Hold there then, the sport will be to what a poor submission—but keep you strong.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I would not see him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes, you shall ring his Knell.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How if I kill him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Kill him? why let him dye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I know 'tis sit so. But why should I that lov'd him once, destroy him? O had he scap't this sin, what a brave Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I must confess, had this not faln, a nobler, a handsomer, the whole VVorld had not show'd ye: And to his making such a mind—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Tis certain: But all this I must now forget.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You shall not if I have any art: go up sweet Lady, and trust my truth.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But good Sir bring him not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I would not for the honour ye are born to, but you shall see him, and neglect him too, and scorn him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You will be near me then.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I will be with ye; yet there's some hope to stop this gap, I'll work hard.

div.head: Scaene 2.
div.stage: Enter Antigonus, Menip. two Gent. Lieutenant, and Lords.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But is it possible this Fellow took it?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: It seems so by the violence it wrought with, yet now the fits ev'n off.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I beseech your Grace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, I forgive thy Wife with all my heart, and am right-glad she drank it not her self, and more glad that the vertuous Maid escap't it, I would not for the VVorld 'thad hit: but that this Souldier, Lord how he looks, that he should take this Vomit; Can he make Rimes too?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: H'as made a thousand, Sir, and playes the burthen to 'em on a Jews-trump.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He looks as though he were Bepist: Do you love me Sir?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Yes surely even with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I thank ye; I am glad I have so good a subject: But pray ye tell me, How much did ye love me, before ye drank this matter?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Even as much as a sober Man might; and a Souldier that your Grace owes just half a years pay to.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well remembred; And did I seem so young and amiable to ye?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Methought you were the sweetest youth—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That's excellent.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I truly Sir: and ever as I thought on ye, I wished, and wished—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What didst thou wish prithee?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Lv'n, that I had been a Wench of Fifteen for ye, a handsom Wench Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why? God a Mercy Souldier: I seem not so now to thee.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Not all out: and yet I have a grudging to your Grace still.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou wast never in love before.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Not with a King, and hope I shall never be again: Truly Sir, I have had such plunges, and such bickrings, and as it were such runnings atilt within me, for whatsoever it was provok't me toward ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: God a-mercy still

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I had it with a vengeance, it plaid his prize.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would not have been a wench then, though of this age.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: No sure, I should have spoil'd ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, go thy ways, of all the lusty lovers that e're I saw— wilt have another potion?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: If you will be another thing, have at ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha: give me thy hand, from henceforth thou art my souldier, do bravely, I'll love thee as much.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: I thank ye; but if you were mine enemy, I would not wish it ye: I beseech your Grace, pay me my charge.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: That's certain Sir; h'as bought up all that e're he found was like ye, or any thing you have lov'd, that he could purchase; old horses, that your Grace has ridden blind, and foundr'd; dogs, rotten kawks, and which is more than all this, has worn your Graces Gauntlet in his Bonnet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Bring in your Bills: mine own love shall be satisfi'd; and sarrah, for this potion you have taken, I'll point ye out a portion ye shall live on.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: 'Twas the best draught that e're ye drunk.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are the Princes come toth' Court?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: They are all, and lodg'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come then, make ready for their entertainment, which presently we'l give: wait you on me Sir.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I shall love drink the better whilst I live boyes.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Let me but see her, dear Leontius; let me but dye before her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Would that would do it: if I knew where she lay now, with what honesty, you having flung so main a mischief on her, and on so innocent and sweet a Beauty, dare I present your visit?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'll repent all: and with the greatest sacrifice of sorrow, that ever Lover made.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Twill be too late Sir: I know not what will become of you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You can help me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: It may be to her sight: What are you nearer? She has Sworn she will not speak to ye, look upon ye, and to Love ye again, O she cries out, and thunders, she had rather love— there is no hope—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
Yes
〈◊〉 , there is a hope, which though it draw no Love to it, at least will draw her to lament my fortune, and that hope shall relieve me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hark ye Sir, hark ye: say I should bring ye—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Do not trifle with me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I will not trifle; both together bring ye, you know the wrongs ye' done.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I do confess 'em.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And if you should then jump into your fury, and have another Querk in your head.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I'll dye first.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You must say nothing to her; for 'tis certain, the nature of your crime will admit to excuse.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will not speak, mine eyes shall tell my Penance.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You must look wondrous sad too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I need not look so, I am truly sadness self.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That look will do it: stay here, I'll bring her to you instantly: but take heed how you bear your self: sit down there, the more humble you are, the more she'll take compassion. Women are per'lous thing to deal upon.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What shall become of me? to curse my fortune were but to curse my Father; that's too impious; but under whatsoever fate I suffer, bless I beseech thee, Heaven, her harmless goodness.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now arm your self.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You have not brought him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Yes Faith, and there he is: you see in what poor plight too, now you may do your will, kill him, or save him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I will go back.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will be hang'd then Lady, Are ye a Coward now?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I cannot speak to him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: There was a Sigh to blow a Church down; So, now their eyes are fixt, the Small-shot plays, they will come toth' Battery anon.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: He weeps extreamly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Rail at him now.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nor dare believe his Tears.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: You may, blest Beauty, for those thick streams that troubled my Repentance, are crept out long ago.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You see how he looks.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: What have I to do how he looks? How lookt he then, when with a poison'd Tooth he bit mine honour? It was your Counsel too, to scorn and slight him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I, if ye saw sit cause; and you confest too, except this sin, he was the bravest Gentleman, the sweetest, noblest. I take nothing from ye, nor from your anger; use him as you please: for to say truth, he has deserv'd your Justice; but still consider what he has been to you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pray do not blind me thus.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: O Gentle Mistriss, If there were any way to expiate a sin so great as mine, by intercession, by prayers, by daily tears, by dying for ye: O what a joy would close these eyes that love ye.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: They say Women have tender hearts, I know not, I am sure mine melts.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir, I forgive ye heartily,
And all your wrong to me I cast behind me,
And wish ye a sit beauty to your Vertues:
Mine is too poor, in peace I thus part from you:
I must look back: gods keep your grace: he's here still.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: She has forgiven me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: She has directed ye: Up, up, and follow like a Man: away Sir, She lookt behind her twice: her heart dwells here Sir, ye drew tears from her too: she cannot freeze thus; the Door's set open too, Are ye a Man? are ye alive? Do ye understand her meaning? Have ye blood and spirit in ye?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I dare not trouble her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nay, and you will be nipt i'th' head with nothing,
Walk whining up and down; I dare not, I cannot:
Strike now or never: faint heart, you know what Sir—
Be govern'd by your fear, and quench your fire out.
A Devil on't, stands this door ope for nothing?
So get ye together, and be naught: now to secure all,
Will I go fetch out a more soveraign Plaister.

div.head: Scaene 4.
div.stage: Enter Antigonus, Seleucus, Lysimachus, Ptolomy, Lieutenant, Gentlemen, Lords.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This peace is fairly made.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: Would your Grace wish us to put in more: take what you please, we yield it; the honour done us by your Son constrains it, your noble Son.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is sufficient, Princes; and now we are one again, one mind, one body, and one sword shall strike for us.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Let Prince Demetrius but lead us on: for we are his vowed servants; against the strength of all the World we'll buckle.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: And even from all that strength we'll catch at Victory.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: O had I now recover'd but the fortune I lost in Antioch, when mine Unckle perish'd; but that were but to surfeit me with blessings.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: You lost a sweet Child there.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Name it no more Sir; this is no time to entertain such sorrows; Will your Majesty do us the honour, we may see the Prince, and wait upon him?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wonder he stays from us: [Enter Leon.
How now Leonitus, Where's my Son?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Brave Captain.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Old valiant Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Your Graces are welcome: your son and't please you Sir, is new cashiered yonder, cast from his Mistris favour: and such a coil there is; such fending, and such proving; she stands off, and will by no means yield to composition: he offers any price; his body to her.

sp.speaker: Sel
sp.l: She is a hard Lady, denyes that caution.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And now they whine, and now they rave: faith Princes, 'twere a good point of charity to piece 'em; for less than such a power will do just nothing: and if you mean to see him, there it must be, for there will he grow, till he be transplanted.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Beseech your grace, let's wait upon you thither, that I may see that beauty dares deny him, that scornful beauty.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: I should think it worse now; ill brought up beauty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: She has too much reason sor't; which with too great a grief, I shame to think of, but we'll go see this game.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Rather this wonder.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Be you our guide Leontius, here's a new peace.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Thus far you shall perswade me, still to honour ye, still to live with ye, Sir, or near about ye; for not to lye, you have my first and last love but since you have conceiv'd an evil against me, an evil that so much concerns your honour, that honour aim'd by all at for a pattern: and though there be a false thought, and confest too, and much repentance faln in showrs to purge it; yet, whilest that great respect I ever bore ye, dwells in my blood, and in my heart that duty; had it but been a dream, I must not touch ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O you will make some other happy?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Never, upon this hand I'll seal that faith.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: We may kiss, put not those out o'th' peace too.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
Those I'll give ye, so there you will be pleas'd to pitch your
〈◊〉 ultra, I will be merry with ye; sing, discourse with ye, be your poor Mistriss still: in truth I love ye.
sp.stage: Enter Leontius, Antigonus, 〈◊〉 , Lysimachus, Ptolomie, Lieutenant, and Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Stay, who are these?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: A very handsome Lady.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: As 〈◊〉 you saw.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Pity her heart's so cruel.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: How does your Grace? he stands still, will not hear us.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: We come to serve ye, Sir, in all our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: He bows a little now; he's strangely alter'd.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p:
Ha? pray ye a word Leontius, pray a word with ye, Lysimachus?
you both knew mine Enanthe, I lost in Antioch, when the Town was taken, mine Uncle slain, Antigonus had the sack on't?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Yes, I remember well the Girl.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Methinks now that face is wondrous like her: I have her picture, the same, but more years on her; the very same.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: A Cherry to a Cherry is not liker.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sook on her eyes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Most certain she is like her: many a time have I dandled her in these arms, Sir, and I hope who will more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's that ye look at, Princes?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: This Picture, and that Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha! they are near: they only err in time.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Did you mark that blush there? that came the nearest.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I must speak to her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You'll quickly be resolved.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Your name sweet Lady?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Enanthe, Sir: and this to beg your blessing.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If you be the King Seleucus, I know you are my Father.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Peace a little, where did I lose ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: At the Sack of Antioch, where my good Uncle dy'd, and I was taken, by a mean Souldier taken: by this Prince, this noble Prince, redeem'd from him again, where ever since I have remain'd his Servant.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: My joys are now too full: welcome Enanthe, mine own, my dearest, and my best Enanthe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And mine too desperate.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You shall not think so, this is a peace indeed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I hope it shall be, and ask it first.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Most Royal Sir, ye have it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I once more beg it thus.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You must not be deny'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: By me, I am sure he must not: sure he shall not; kneeling I give it too; kneeling I take it; and from this hour, no envious spight e're part us.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: The gods give happy joyes; all comforts to ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My new Enanthe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, beat all the Drumes up, and all the noble instruments of War: let 'em sill all the Kingdom with their sounds: and those the brazen Arch of Heaven break through, while to the Temple we conduct these two.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: May they be ever loving, ever young, and ever worthy of those lines they sprung; may their fair issues walk with time along.

sp.l: And hang a Coward now; and there's my song.
